abstract: In this study we examined the effect of oxidized low density lipoprotein (ox-LDL) on the intracellular production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in bovine aortic endothelial cells (BAECs) and whether this increase occurs through its binding to the endothelial receptor lectin-like ox-LDL receptor-1 (LOX-1). Furthermore, this study also aimed to ascertain whether the binding of ox-LDL to LOX-1 is associated with NF-κB activation. ox-LDL induced a significant dose-dependent increase in ROS production after a 30-s incubation with BAECs (p < 0.01). ROS formation was markedly reduced in BAECs incubated with anti-LOX-1 monoclonal antibody (p < 0.001), while control nonimmune IgG produced no effect. ox-LDL induced a time- and dose-dependent significant increase in ROS formation only in CHO-K1 cells stably expressing bovine LOX-1 (p < 0.001), while no increase was present in CHO-K1 cells. The activation of the transcription factor NF-κB in BAECs was evident after a 5-min incubation with ox-LDL and was attenuated by anti-LOX-1 monoclonal antibody. The conclusion is that one of the pathophysiological consequences of ox-LDL binding to LOX-1 may be the activation of NF-κB through an increased ROS production. Furthermore, this study also aimed to ascertain whether the binding of ox-LDL to LOX-1 is associated with NF-κB activation. ox-LDL induced a significant dose-dependent increase in ROS production after a 30-s incubation with BAECs (p < 0.01). The activation of the transcription factor NF-κB in BAECs was evident after a 5-min incubation with ox-LDL and was attenuated by anti-LOX-1 monoclonal antibody. It is not clear, however, if these effects are unspecifically related to some peroxidative products of the lipoprotein or due to a more specific mechanism. Recently, a novel receptor for ox-LDL, designated lectin-like ox-LDL receptor-1 (LOX-1) was cloned from cultured bovine aortic endothelial cells (BAECs) (21.Sawamura T. Kume N. Aoyama T. Moriwaki H. Hoshikawa H. Aiba Y. Tanaka T. Miwa S. Katsura Y. Kita T. Masaki T. Nature. 1997; 386: 73-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (1155) Google Scholar). It has a type II membrane protein structure with a short N-terminal cytosolic domain and a long C-terminal extracellular domain but is distinct from type I and type II scavenger receptors (21.Sawamura T. Kume N. Aoyama T. Moriwaki H. Hoshikawa H. Aiba Y. Tanaka T. Miwa S. Katsura Y. Kita T. Masaki T. Nature. 1997; 386: 73-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (1155) Google Scholar). Although the potential roles of this receptor in atherogenesis are not yet fully understood, it has been suggested that ox-LDL uptake through this receptor expressed on the surface of vascular endothelium may be involved in endothelial activation or dysfunction in atherogenesis (21.Sawamura T. Kume N. Aoyama T. Moriwaki H. Hoshikawa H. Aiba Y. Tanaka T. Miwa S. Katsura Y. Kita T. Masaki T. Nature. 1997; 386: 73-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (1155) Google Scholar).In this report, we investigated the effect of ox-LDL on the intracellular production of ROS in cultures of BAECs and whether the intracellular increase of ROS induced by ox-LDL is mediated by binding to a specific endothelial receptor. Furthermore, since intracellularly ROS play a major role in the translocation of NF-κB (13.Iademarco M.F. McQuillan J.J. Rosen G.D. Dean D.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 16323-16329Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 22.Neish A.S. Williams A.J. Palmer H.J. Whitley M.Z. Collins T. J. Exp. Med. 1992; 176: 1583-1593Crossref PubMed Scopus (384) Google Scholar), this study also aimed to ascertain whether the binding of ox-LDL to LOX-1 is associated with NF-κB activation.RESULTSThe exposure of 1.7 mg of LDL protein/ml of n-LDL to 5 μm Cu2+ for 18 at 37 °C resulted in a significant increase of thiobarbituric acid-reactive substances (12.7 ± 1.4 nmol/mg LDL protein) compared with n-LDL (0.29 ± 0.03 nmol/mg of LDL protein) (p < 0.01).The incubation of BAECs with increasing amounts of ox-LDL (50–150 μg of LDL protein/ml) for 5 min induced a dose-dependent, significant increase in DCF formation (p < 0.001), while no increase was present with n-LDL, Ac-LDL and MDA-LDL, even at the highest concentration (150 μg of LDL protein/ml). Fig.1 a shows the effect of n-LDL, Ac-LDL and MDA-LDL and of increasing amounts of ox-LDL on DCF formation in BAECs.We also performed some time course experiments of DCF formation in BAECs. As shown in Fig. 1 b, from the evaluation of the time course of DCF formation in BAECs, it was evident that the effect of ox-LDL was already present after 30 s of incubation.To test the specificity of DCF increase induced by ox-LDL in BAECs (i.e. whether or not it depended on ROS production), we preincubated BAECs with different antioxidants, known to work as radical scavengers. As shown in Fig. 2, the preincubation of BAECs with trolox, vitamin C, and probucol significantly reduced the ox-LDL-induced DCF production (p < 0.001).Figure 2Effect of preincubation of BAECs with trolox, vitamin C, and probucol on ox-LDL-induced DCF formation. BAECs were preincubated with DCFH-DA, a dye that allows the monitoring of intracellular reactive oxygen species production by flow cytometry evaluation of DCF for 45 min at 37 °C. Trolox, vitamin C, and probucol (all at a concentration of 5 μm) were also preincubated with BAECs for 30 min at 37 °C. Thereafter, ox-LDL (50 μg of LDL protein/ml) was added for 5 min at 37 °C. Results are expressed as percentage variation (Δ%) of MFI versusox-LDL alone (100%) and are the means ± S.D. of experiments performed in triplicate on six separate occasions. *, p< 0.001 versus ox-LDL.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Furthermore, we investigated the H2O2 and O⨪2 formation in BAECs induced by ox-LDL. In our experimental conditions, ox-LDL triggered a strong and dose-dependent production of H2O2 after a 5-min incubation. With 50 μg of LDL protein/ml of ox-LDL the mean value of H2O2 was 1.2 ± 0.3 nmol/106cells. An almost identical response was seen for the production of O⨪2 with mean values of 5.6 ± 0.4 nmol/106cells for 50 μg of LDL protein/ml of ox-LDL.In order to ascertain whether the effect of ox-LDL on DCF formation was mediated through the binding of the lipoprotein to a specific receptor on BAECs, binding tests with labeled ox-LDL were performed in BAECs and BLOX-1-CHO cells. The dose-response relationship in di-15-ASP-labeled ox-LDL binding to BAECs and BLOX-1-CHO cells showed saturation kinetics, and a 100-fold excess of unlabeled ox-LDL completely inhibited di-15-ASP-labeled ox-LDL binding to BAECs and BLOX-1-CHO cells (data not shown). Scatchard analysis revealed that di-15-ASP-labeled ox-LDL can bind to BAECs and BLOX-1-CHO cells with a constant dissociation ranging from 29 to 41 μg/ml.To further characterize the binding properties of the receptor, the receptor activity was measured in presence of various inhibitors. Ox-LDL, anti-LOX-1 mAb, and poly I significantly reduced di-15-ASP-labeled ox-LDL binding to BAECs and BLOX-1-CHO cells (p < 0.001); on the contrary, n-LDL, Ac-LDL, class A scavenger receptor inhibitor fucoidin, and control IgG did not affect di-15-ASP-labeled ox-LDL binding to BAECs and BLOX-1-CHO cells (data not shown). Fig. 3 shows the effect of ox-LDL, of anti-LOX-1 mAb, and of poly I on di-15-ASP-labeled ox-LDL binding to BAECs and BLOX-1-CHO cells.Figure 3Effect of ox-LDL , anti-LOX-1 mAb , and poly I on di-15-ASP-labeled ox-LDL (see “Materials and Methods”) binding to BAECs and to BLOX-1-CHO cells. BAECs and BLOX-1-CHO cells grown to confluence in 24-well plates were incubated with 6.25 μg of LDL protein/ml of di-15-ASP-labeled ox-LDL at 4 °C for 2 h in the presence of various inhibitors. Ox-LDL (100-fold excess amount), anti-LOX-1 mAb (30 μg/ml), and poly I (250 μg/ml) were used as inhibitors. After a 2-h incubation, the binding of di-15-ASP-labeled ox-LDL to BAECs and BLOX-1-CHO cells was measured in flow cytometry. Results are expressed as percentage variation (Δ%) of MFIversus di-15-ASP-labeled ox-LDL binding to BAECs and to BLOX-1-CHO cells with no competitors (None) (100%) and are the means ± S.D. of experiments performed in triplicate on six separate occasions. *, p < 0.001 versusnone.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)On the basis of the results indicated above, to verify if ox-LDL-induced DCF formation in BAECs occurred through a binding to LOX-1, we used anti-LOX-1 mAb as well as CHO-K1 and BLOX-1-CHO cells. As shown in Fig. 4, the DCF formation was markedly reduced in BAECs incubated with anti-LOX-1 mAb (p < 0.001), while control IgG produced no effect. ox-LDL induced a dose- and time-dependent significant increase in DCF formation only in BLOX-1-CHO cells (p< 0.001), while no increase was present in CHO-K1 cells (Fig.5, a and b). Similarly to BAECs, n-LDL, MDA-LDL, and Ac-LDL had no effect on DCF production in BLOX-1-CHO cells.Figure 4Effect of preincubation of BAECs with anti-LOX-1 mAb on ox-LDL-induced DCF formation. BAECs were preincubated with DCFH-DA, a dye that allows the monitoring of intracellular reactive oxygen species production by flow cytometry evaluation of DCF, for 45 min at 37 °C. Anti-LOX-1 mAb (30 μg/ml) or comparable amounts of nonimmune mouse IgG (IgG) were also preincubated with BAECs for 40 min at 37 °C. Thereafter, ox-LDL (50 μg of LDL protein/ml) was added for 5 min at 37 °C. Results are expressed as MFI and are the means ± S.D. of experiments performed in triplicate on six separate occasions. *, p< 0.001 versus ox-LDL.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Figure 5A, effect of increasing amounts of ox-LDL on DCF formation in BLOX-1-CHO and in CHO-K1 cells. BLOX-1-CHO and CHO-K1 cells were preincubated with DCFH-DA, a dye that allows the monitoring of intracellular reactive oxygen species production by flow cytometry evaluation of DCF, for 45 min at 37 °C. Increasing amounts of ox-LDL (50–150 μg of LDL protein/ml) were then incubated with BLOX-1-CHO and CHO-K1 cells for 5 min. Results are expressed as MFI and are the means ± S.D. of experiments performed in triplicate on six separate occasions. *, p < 0.001 versuscontrol. B, time course of DCF formation induced by ox-LDL in BLOX-1-CHO and CHO-K1 cells. BLOX-1-CHO and CHO-K1 cells were preincubated with DCFH-DA, a dye that allows the monitoring of intracellular reactive oxygen species production by flow cytometry evaluation of DCF, for 45 min at 37 °C. 100 μg of LDL protein/ml of ox-LDL were then incubated with BLOX-1-CHO and CHO-K1 cells for the indicated times. Results are expressed as MFI and are the means ± S.D. of experiments performed in triplicate.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Moreover the effect of anti-LOX-1 mAb on DCF formation in BLOX-1 CHO cells was investigated. As shown in Fig.6, the DCF formation was markedly reduced also in BLOX-1-CHO cells incubated with anti-LOX-1 mAb (p < 0.001); control IgG produced no effect.Figure 6Effect of preincubation of BLOX-1-CHO cells with anti-LOX-1 mAb on ox-LDL-induced DCF formation. BLOX-1-CHO cells were preincubated with DCFH-DA, a dye that allows the monitoring of intracellular reactive oxygen species production by flow cytometry evaluation of DCF, for 45 min at 37 °C. Anti-LOX-1 mAb (30 μg/ml) or comparable amounts of nonimmune mouse IgG (IgG) were also preincubated with BLOX-1-CHO cells for 40 min at 37 °C. Thereafter, ox-LDL (50 μg of LDL protein/ml) was added for 5 min at 37 °C. Results are expressed as MFI and are the means ± S.D. of experiments performed in triplicate on six separate occasions. *,p < 0.001 versus ox-LDL.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Finally, the effect of ox-LDL on NF-κB activation on BAECs was studied. In order to ascertain a causal relationship between ox-LDL-induced DCF formation and NF-κB activation, a time course study was performed. In our experimental conditions, the activation of NF-κB showed a kinetic profile similar to DCF formation, with evident activation starting from 5 min of incubation (Fig.7). Furthermore, the effect of anti-LOX-1 mAb on ox-LDL-induced NF-κB activation was also investigated. As shown in Fig. 7, the activation of NF-κB was attenuated in BAECs incubated with anti-LOX-1 mAb.Figure 7EMSA showing the effect of ox-LDL and of preincubation with anti-LOX-1 mAb on NF-κB activation in BAECs. Nuclear extracts from BAECs treated for the indicated periods of time with 100 μg of LDL protein/ml and with anti-LOX-1 mAb (30 μg/ml) were prepared and analyzed by EMSA as described under “Materials and Methods.” As a positive control, nuclear extracts of BAECs treated with human recombinant TNF-α (2 ng/ml) for 5 min were also prepared and analyzed by EMSA. Supershift assay was performed with affinity-purified polyclonal antibodies to NF-κB p65 and p50. The specificity of the NF-κB band was demonstrated by treating the nuclear protein of positive control extracts with an excess of cold competitor probe. Lane 1, control; lane 2, TNF-α;lane 3, ox-LDL (1-min incubation);lane 4, ox-LDL (5-min incubation);lane 5, ox-LDL (1-min incubation) with preincubation with anti-LOX-1 mAb; lane 6, ox-LDL (5 min incubation) with preincubation with anti-LOX-1 mAb;lane 7, supershift; lane 8, excess cold competitor. NF-kB, specific binding to the probe; N.S., nonspecific binding to the probe.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)DISCUSSIONIn this study, we showed that ox-LDL increased the intracellular formation of ROS in aortic endothelial cells. We found that ox-LDL is a strong inducer of intracellular ROS production by two distinct approaches. First, ox-LDL was shown to increase the intracellular oxidation of the dye DCFH, a process that has already been demonstrated to depend on the intracellular production of ROS (33.Zulueta J.J. Sawhney R. Feng S.Y. Cote C.C. Hassoun P.M. Am. J. Physiol. 1997; 272: L897-L902Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 37.Cominacini L. Garbin U. Fratta Pasini A. Davoli A. Campagnola M. Pastorino A.M. Gaviraghi G. Lo Cascio V. J. Hypertens. 1998; 16: 1913-1919Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 40.Schmidt K.M. Traenckner E.B. Meier B. Baeuerle P.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 27136-27142Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar). Second, an increased H2O2 and O⨪2 production was directly measured in culture supernatants of BAECs. The increased intracellular production of ROS was prevented by preincubating BAECs with different antioxidants, known to work as radical scavengers. These data support the conclusion that the incubation of ox-LDL with BAECs is associated with an increased intracellular production of ROS and that the rise in DCF formation is specifically related to ROS formation. Our results agree with the conclusions of a series of papers showing that ox-LDL increased the production of ROS in different cells (18.Tsao P.S. Buitrago R. Chan J.R. Cooke J.P. Circulation. 1996; 94: 1682-1689Crossref PubMed Scopus (259) Google Scholar, 19.Maeba R. Maruyama A. Tarutani O. Ueta N. Shimasaki H. FEBS Lett. 1995; 377: 309-312Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar, 20.Kimura H. Minakami H. Kimura S. Sakurai T. Nakamura T. Kurashige S. Nakano M. Shoji A. Atherosclerosis. 1995; 118: 1-8Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar, 37.Cominacini L. Garbin U. Fratta Pasini A. Davoli A. Campagnola M. Pastorino A.M. Gaviraghi G. Lo Cascio V. J. Hypertens. 1998; 16: 1913-1919Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar).The peculiarity of this study stems from the fact that the increase in intracellular ROS formation induced by ox-LDL in BAECs was very fast, the signal of ROS production being clearly visible even after 30 s. This suggests that intracellular ROS increase may be secondary to ox-LDL ligation to a specific receptor on BAECs. Based on this evidence, we first characterized the binding of ox-LDL to BAECs and to BLOX-1-CHO cells. We found that ox-LDL bound to BAECs and to BLOX-1-CHO cells with a constant dissociation similar to that reported by Sawamuraet al. (21.Sawamura T. Kume N. Aoyama T. Moriwaki H. Hoshikawa H. Aiba Y. Tanaka T. Miwa S. Katsura Y. Kita T. Masaki T. Nature. 1997; 386: 73-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (1155) Google Scholar) and Moriwaki et al. (41.Moriwaki H. Kume N. Sawamura T. Aoyama T. Hoshikawa H. Ochi H. Nishi E. Masaki T. Kita T. Arterioscler. Thromb. Vasc. Biol. 1998; 18: 1541-1547Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar). Furthermore, as previously reported, the pretreatment of cells with an excess amount of ox-LDL, poly I, and anti-LOX-1 mAb consistently reduced the binding to BAECs and to BLOX-1-CHO cells (21.Sawamura T. Kume N. Aoyama T. Moriwaki H. Hoshikawa H. Aiba Y. Tanaka T. Miwa S. Katsura Y. Kita T. Masaki T. Nature. 1997; 386: 73-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (1155) Google Scholar, 41.Moriwaki H. Kume N. Sawamura T. Aoyama T. Hoshikawa H. Ochi H. Nishi E. Masaki T. Kita T. Arterioscler. Thromb. Vasc. Biol. 1998; 18: 1541-1547Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar). On the contrary, no effect was obtained with fucoidin, a class A scavenger receptor inhibitor, n-LDL, and Ac-LDL (21.Sawamura T. Kume N. Aoyama T. Moriwaki H. Hoshikawa H. Aiba Y. Tanaka T. Miwa S. Katsura Y. Kita T. Masaki T. Nature. 1997; 386: 73-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (1155) Google Scholar, 41.Moriwaki H. Kume N. Sawamura T. Aoyama T. Hoshikawa H. Ochi H. Nishi E. Masaki T. Kita T. Arterioscler. Thromb. Vasc. Biol. 1998; 18: 1541-1547Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar). Observed together, these results clearly indicate that the molecular mechanisms of ox-LDL binding to LOX-1 are distinct from those of scavenger receptors, such as CD36 and SR-B1 (41.Moriwaki H. Kume N. Sawamura T. Aoyama T. Hoshikawa H. Ochi H. Nishi E. Masaki T. Kita T. Arterioscler. Thromb. Vasc. Biol. 1998; 18: 1541-1547Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar). The fact that DCF formation was markedly reduced in BAECs preincubated with anti-LOX-1 mAb, indicates that the ox-LDL ligation to LOX-1 may play a role in intracellular ROS generation. This conclusion is further supported by the results we obtained with BLOX-1-CHO cells where ox-LDL determined a time- and dose-dependent significant increase in DCF formation that could be abolished by anti-LOX-1 mAb preincubation.There are many enzymatic sources for ROS in almost all cell types (42.Lander H.M. FASEB J. 1997; 11: 118-124Crossref PubMed Scopus (819) Google Scholar). It has been hypothesized that the activity or expression of these enzymes can be regulated by cytokines and growth factors (42.Lander H.M. FASEB J. 1997; 11: 118-124Crossref PubMed Scopus (819) Google Scholar). Thus, receptor-ligand interaction is likely to trigger free radical signaling through activation of one or more of these enzymes (42.Lander H.M. FASEB J. 1997; 11: 118-124Crossref PubMed Scopus (819) Google Scholar). In fact, several reports have indicated an increase in ROS upon receptor ligation (43.Ohba M. Shibanuma M. Kuroki T. Nose K. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 126: 1079-1088Crossref PubMed Scopus (430) Google Scholar, 44.Griendling K.K. Minieri C.A. Ollerenshaw J.D. Alexander R.W. Circ. Res. 1994; 74: 1141-1148Crossref PubMed Scopus (2368) Google Scholar, 45.Sunderasan M., Yu, Z-H. Ferrans V.J. Irani K. Finkel T. Science. 1995; 270: 296-299Crossref PubMed Scopus (2300) Google Scholar, 46.Lo Y.Y. Cruz T.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 11727-11730Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (469) Google Scholar, 47.Thannickal V.J. Fanburg B.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 30334-30338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (377) Google Scholar), and in one case, the induction of protein tyrosine phosphorylation in neutrophils was dependent on NADPH oxidase activation (48.Fialkow L. Chan C.K. Gristein S. Downey G.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 17131-17137Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Unfortunately, on the basis of the present results, we cannot draw any conclusion on this particular point, and further studies are needed to confirm that ox-LDL ligation to LOX-1 may affect the triggering of free radicals through the activation of some ROS sources.Finally, the results of this study show that ox-LDL induced NF-κB activation in BAECs. Numerous studies have provided strong support for a proposal that intracellular ROS serve as common intracellular downstream messengers of the various stimulus-specific pathways leading to NF-κB activation (14.Schreck R. Rieber P. Baeuerle P.A. EMBO J. 1991; 10: 2247-2258Crossref PubMed Scopus (3395) Google Scholar, 49.Schreck R. Meier B. Mannel D.M. Droge W. Baeuerle P.A. J. Exp. Thromb. 1994; 14: 1665-1673Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). For example, the potent antioxidants pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate andN-acetylcysteine block NF-κB activation (49.Schreck R. Meier B. Mannel D.M. Droge W. Baeuerle P.A. J. Exp. Med. 1992; 175: 1181-1194Crossref PubMed Scopus (1442) Google Scholar, 50.Weber C. Erl W. Pietsch A. Strobel M. Loms Ziegler-Heitbrock H.W. Weber P.C. Arterioscler. Thromb. 1994; 14: 1665-1673Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), not only by H2O2 and ionizing radiation, but also by nonoxidizing stimuli (50.Weber C. Erl W. Pietsch A. Strobel M. Loms Ziegler-Heitbrock H.W. Weber P.C. Arterioscler. Thromb. 1994; 14: 1665-1673Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The activation of NF-κB by H2O2 and other stimuli can be suppressed by herbimycin A and tryphostin 47 (51.Smith W.L. Marnett L.J. De Witt D.L. Pharmacol. Ther. 1991; 49: 153-179Crossref PubMed Scopus (386) Google Scholar), suggesting the involvement of a redox-sensitive protein-tyrosine kinase in the activation process. We recently found that ox-LDL and TNF-α increased the expression of adhesion molecules on endothelial cells through NF-κB activation (8.Cominacini L. Garbin U. Fratta Pasini A. Davoli A. NF-κB activity did not strongly increase before 5 min after the addition of 50 μg of LDL protein/ml of ox-LDL. These data show that NF-κB activation follows the prod

Wnt ligands working through Frizzled receptors have a differential ability to stimulate release of intracellular calcium (Ca2+) and activation of protein kinase C (PKC). Since targets of this Ca2+ release could play a role in Wnt signaling, we first tested the hypothesis that Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II (CamKII) is activated by some Wnt and Frizzled homologs. We report that Wnt and Frizzled homologs that activate Ca2+ release and PKC also activate CamKII activity in Xenopus embryos, while Wnt and Frizzled homologs that activate β-catenin function do not. This activation occurs within 10 min after receptor activation in a pertussis toxin-sensitive manner, concomitant with autophosphorylation of endogenous CamKII. Based on data that Wnt-5A and Wnt-11 are present maternally in Xenopus eggs, and activate CamKII, we then tested the hypothesis that CamKII participates in axis formation in the early embryo. Measurements of endogenous CamKII activity from dorsal and ventral regions of embryos revealed elevated activity on the prospective ventral side, which was suppressed by a dominant negative Xwnt-11. If this spatial bias in CamKII activity were involved in promoting ventral cell fate one might predict that elevating CamKII activity on the dorsal side would inhibit dorsal cell fates, while reducing CamKII activity on the ventral side would promote dorsal cell fates. Results obtained by expression of CamKII mutants were consistent with this prediction, revealing that CamKII contributes to a ventral cell fate. Results obtained by expression of CamKII mutants were consistent with this prediction, revealing that CamKII contributes to a ventral cell fate. calcium/calmodulin-dependent kinase β2-adrenergic receptor Frizzled goosecoid protein kinase C Xenopus nodal related-3 The Wnt gene family encodes a group of secreted glycoproteins implicated as ligands in cell signaling in both vertebrates and invertebrates. Wnts are involved in diverse developmental processes, including cell differentiation, cell migration, cell polarity, and cell proliferation (reviewed in Ref. 2.Wodarz A. Nusse R. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1998; 14: 59-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (1743) Google Scholar). Unregulated activation of Wnt signaling has also been linked to a variety of human cancers (reviewed in Refs. 1.Miller J.R. Hocking A.M. Brown J.D. Moon R.T. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 7860-7862Crossref PubMed Scopus (607) Google Scholar and 2.Wodarz A. Nusse R. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1998; 14: 59-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (1743) Google Scholar). The best understood Wnt signaling pathway is stimulated by wingless in Drosophila, and by its counterpart, Wnt-1, in vertebrates (reviewed in Refs. 1.Miller J.R. Hocking A.M. Brown J.D. Moon R.T. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 7860-7862Crossref PubMed Scopus (607) Google Scholar and 2.Wodarz A. Nusse R. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1998; 14: 59-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (1743) Google Scholar). In this pathway, in the absence of a Wnt signal a serine-threonine kinase, glycogen synthase kinase-3, promotes the phosphorylation and degradation of β-catenin, facilitated by the adaptor proteins adenomatous polyposis coli and axin. Stimulation of the Wnt pathway activates Dishevelled, which in turn reduces the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation. Dishevelled may be regulated by two kinases, casein kinase I (3.Peters J.M. McKay R.M. McKay J.P. Graff J.M. Nature. 1999; 401: 345-350Crossref PubMed Scopus (385) Google Scholar) and casein kinase II (4.Willert K. Brink M. Wodarz A. Varmus H. Nusse R. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3089-3096Crossref PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar). As β-catenin levels increase, it forms complexes with the HMG box transcription factors TCF and LEF, activating expression of target genes. Since there are likely to be at least 18 vertebrate Wnt genes (reviewed in Ref. 2.Wodarz A. Nusse R. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1998; 14: 59-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (1743) Google Scholar), it is reasonable to ask if cells respond to expression of these Wnts in an identical manner. Ectopic expression of one group of Wnts, including Wnt-1, -3A, -8, and -8b, on the ventral side of cleaving Xenopus embryos leads to induction of a secondary body axis in Xenopus (reviewed in Ref. 5.Moon R.T. Brown J.D. Torres M. Trends Genet. 1997; 13: 157-162Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (548) Google Scholar). Many of the same Wnts are transforming in C57mg mammary epithelial cells (6.Wong G.T. Gavin B.J. McMahon A.P. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 6278-6286Crossref PubMed Scopus (285) Google Scholar). In both assays, the cellular response is attributed to the Wnts activating a signaling pathway that promotes the stabilization and activity of the multi-functional protein β-catenin (reviewed in Refs. 1.Miller J.R. Hocking A.M. Brown J.D. Moon R.T. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 7860-7862Crossref PubMed Scopus (607) Google Scholar, 2.Wodarz A. Nusse R. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1998; 14: 59-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (1743) Google Scholar, and 7.Miller J.R. Moon R.T. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 2527-2539Crossref PubMed Scopus (608) Google Scholar). Other Wnts, including Wnt-4, -5A, and -11, do not induce formation of a secondary axis in Xenopus nor do they transform C57mg cells. Data suggest that the non axis-inducing, non-transforming Wnts are nevertheless biologically active. First, when overexpressed inXenopus embryos these Wnts are able to antagonize axis induction by the transforming Wnts and to elicit a distinct phenotype (8.Du S.J. Purcell S.M. Christian J.L. McGrew L.L. Moon R.T. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 2625-2634Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9.Torres M.A. Yang-Snyder J.A. Purcell S.M. DeMarais A.A. McGrew L.L. Moon R.T. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 133: 1123-1137Crossref PubMed Scopus (343) Google Scholar). Second, the non-transforming Wnts elicit intracellular Ca2+ release (10.Slusarski D.C. Yang-Snyder J. Busa W.B. Moon R.T. Dev. Biol. 1997; 182: 114-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar, 11.Slusarski D.C. Corces V. Moon R.T. Nature. 1997; 390: 410-413Crossref PubMed Scopus (551) Google Scholar) and activate PKC (Ref. 12.Sheldahl L.C. Park M. Malbon C.C. Moon R.T. Curr. Biol. 1999; 9: 695-698Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (404) Google Scholar, reviewed in Ref. 1.Miller J.R. Hocking A.M. Brown J.D. Moon R.T. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 7860-7862Crossref PubMed Scopus (607) Google Scholar). In contrast, the transforming/axis-inducing Wnts do not stimulate Ca2+ release nor do they activate PKC. Third, Wnts have been shown to signal through receptors belonging to the Frizzled gene family (reviewed Refs. 1.Miller J.R. Hocking A.M. Brown J.D. Moon R.T. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 7860-7862Crossref PubMed Scopus (607) Google Scholar and 2.Wodarz A. Nusse R. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1998; 14: 59-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (1743) Google Scholar), and Frizzled homologs have been shown to preferentially stimulate either β-catenin, or the activation of Ca2+ and PKC (10.Slusarski D.C. Yang-Snyder J. Busa W.B. Moon R.T. Dev. Biol. 1997; 182: 114-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar, 11.Slusarski D.C. Corces V. Moon R.T. Nature. 1997; 390: 410-413Crossref PubMed Scopus (551) Google Scholar, 12.Sheldahl L.C. Park M. Malbon C.C. Moon R.T. Curr. Biol. 1999; 9: 695-698Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (404) Google Scholar). Fourth, in the chick limb Wnt-3A works through the β-catenin pathway while Wnt-7a works through a β-catenin-independent intracellular pathway (13.Kengaku M. Capdevila J. Rodriguez-Esteban C. De La Pena J. Johnson R.L. Belmonte J.C.I. Tabin C.J. Science. 1998; 280: 1274-1277Crossref PubMed Scopus (366) Google Scholar). Interestingly, some Wnts may couple to both pathways. For example, Wnt-5A can become axis inducing in Xenopus when co-expressed with human Frizzled-5 (14.He X. Saint-Jeannet J.P. Wang Y. Nathans J. Dawid I. Varmus H. Science. 1997; 275: 1652-1654Crossref PubMed Scopus (419) Google Scholar). One could interpret these data to conclude that Wnt-5A is not axis inducing in the absence of Frizzled-5 because there is no Wnt-5A receptor present. However, the demonstrated ability of Wnt-5A to antagonize axis induction by Wnt-8 (9.Torres M.A. Yang-Snyder J.A. Purcell S.M. DeMarais A.A. McGrew L.L. Moon R.T. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 133: 1123-1137Crossref PubMed Scopus (343) Google Scholar), to stimulate Ca2+ release (10.Slusarski D.C. Yang-Snyder J. Busa W.B. Moon R.T. Dev. Biol. 1997; 182: 114-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar, 11.Slusarski D.C. Corces V. Moon R.T. Nature. 1997; 390: 410-413Crossref PubMed Scopus (551) Google Scholar), and to stimulate PKC activation (12.Sheldahl L.C. Park M. Malbon C.C. Moon R.T. Curr. Biol. 1999; 9: 695-698Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (404) Google Scholar) suggests that Wnt-5A can elicit distinct cellular responses, depending on which receptors are present. Overall, the data suggest that cells and embryos display diversity in their responses to signaling by different Wnt and Frizzled homologs. As mentioned above the protein kinases glycogen synthase kinase-3, casein kinase I, and casein kinase II, have been implicated in modulating the Wnt-1 pathway. Given the evidence that some Wnt and Frizzled homologs stimulate intracellular Ca2+ release and PKC activation, this raises the possibility that other Ca2+-sensitive kinases might be activated by Wnt and Frizzled homologs. One candidate kinase is CamKII,1 a ubiquitous Ca2+-sensitive enzyme that has been proposed to function in very distinct contexts, including mammalian oocyte maturation, neurotransmitter synthesis and release, and long term potentiation (15.Lorca T. Cruzalegui F.H. Fesquet D. Cavadore J.C. Mery J. Means A. Doree M. Nature. 1993; 366: 270-273Crossref PubMed Scopus (411) Google Scholar, 16.Fukunaga K. Stoppini L. Miyamoto E. Muller D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 7863-7867Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 17.Braun A.P. Schulman H. Annu. Rev. Physiol. 1995; 57: 417-445Crossref PubMed Scopus (738) Google Scholar). After activation by Ca2+/calmodulin, CamKII becomes autophosphorylated and shows an autonomous, Ca2+independent activity. Thus, measuring Ca2+-independent CamKII activities in the absence of exogenous calcium allows the determination of the activity of endogenous CamKII just prior to lysis. As CamKII is activated by the phosphatidylinositol pathway in PC 12 cells (18.MacNicol M. Jefferson A.B. Schulman H. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 18055-18058Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and as Xwnt-5A and rat Frizzled-2 (Rfz-2) elevate intracellular Ca2+ levels through activation of the phosphatidylinositol pathway (10.Slusarski D.C. Yang-Snyder J. Busa W.B. Moon R.T. Dev. Biol. 1997; 182: 114-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar, 11.Slusarski D.C. Corces V. Moon R.T. Nature. 1997; 390: 410-413Crossref PubMed Scopus (551) Google Scholar), in the present report we first investigate whether different members of the Wnt and Frizzled gene families activate CamKII. We then test whether CamKII displays dorso-ventral differences in activity in the Xenopus embryo, whether these asymmetries are dependent upon Wnt signaling, and whether CamKII participates in specification of cell fate in the early embryo. The increased activity of CamKII in response to signaling by specific Wnt and Frizzled homologs could be due to an increase in enzyme activity, or to an increase in enzyme level. To distinguish between these possibilities we repeated the assay with added Ca2+to determine the total, Ca2+-dependent CamKII activity, as a measure of total enzyme level. After expression of Wnt and Frizzled homologs we found no statistically significant differences in total activity (Fig. 1 B). By dividing the CamKII activity obtained in the absence of exogenous Ca2+ (Fig.1 A) by that obtained in the presence of exogenous Ca2+ (Fig. 1 B) we calculated a specific, Ca2+ independent activity of 11% of total kinase activity in control embryos compared with 35% in Xwnt-5A injected embryos, 42% in Xwnt-11 injected embryos, or 27% in Rfz-2 injected embryos. This represents a 2.5–3.8-fold increase in the specific activity of CamKII upon expression of Rfz-2, Xwnt-5A, or Xwnt-11. Dose-response studies revealed that even 100 pg of Xwnt-5A RNA were able to induce CamKII at the same level as 1 ng indicating that maximal stimulation has been reached (see Fig. 3 A for data for 100 pg of Xwnt-5A RNA). Addition of exogenous calmodulin did not result in a further increase in total kinase activity (data not shown). Finally, we directly demonstrated by Western blot analysis that neither Xwnt-5A (Fig.1 D) nor Rfz-2 (data not shown) elevated steady-state levels of CamKII. Our data therefore suggest that the intensity of Ca2+ signaling (amplitude and/or frequency) is the limiting factor in CamKII activation in early Xenopus embryos, and that the activation of CamKII by specific Wnt and Frizzled homologs is attributable to an increase in enzyme activity rather than level. Rfz-1/β2-AR does not activate CamKII even in the presence of agonist.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) If Wnt-5A and Rfz-2 function in the same signaling pathway as ligand and receptor, one would predict that they should synergize in their induction of CamKII. To test this hypothesis we first established that a low dose of Xwnt-5A RNA (10 pg) elevated CamKII activity while a low dose of Rfz-2 (50 pg) did not (Fig. 1 C). Co-injection of these doses of Xwnt-5A and Rfz-2 RNAs revealed a synergistic activation of CamKII (Fig. 1 C), suggesting they act in the same signaling pathway. The increase of CamKII activity in Xwnt-5A/Rfz-2 injected embryos with respect to basal activity in control embryos is 2-fold higher than a simple additive activation of CamKII by either component. Since Ca2+ release by either Xwnt-5A or Rfz-2 is sensitive to treatment with pertussis toxin (11.Slusarski D.C. Corces V. Moon R.T. Nature. 1997; 390: 410-413Crossref PubMed Scopus (551) Google Scholar) and since we predict that CamKII activation is downstream of intracellular Ca2+release, we next tested the prediction that CamKII activity should be sensitive to this toxin. We co-injected RNAs encoding Xwnt-5A and pertussis toxin A protomer and observed that the ability of Xwnt-5A to stimulate CamKII activity was blocked by pertussis toxin (Fig.3 A). Thus Xwnt-5A and Rfz-2, previously shown to synergize in inducing intracellular Ca2+ release in a pertussis toxin-sensitive manner (11.Slusarski D.C. Corces V. Moon R.T. Nature. 1997; 390: 410-413Crossref PubMed Scopus (551) Google Scholar), also synergize to induce CamKII activity in a pertussis toxin-sensitive manner. Previous work has shown that CamKII is autophosphorylated during activation (28.Fong Y.-L. Taylor W.L. Means A.R. Soderling T.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 16759-16763Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 29.Kuret J. Schulman H. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 6427-6433Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). If Xwnt-5A and Rfz-2 are indeed activators of CamKII then they should increase its phosphorylation. We therefore immunoprecipitated total CamKII from cytoplasmic lysates of injected embryos, blotted the immunoprecipitates, and probed with an antiserum specific for the Thr286-autophosphorylated form of CamKII. Consistent with the enzyme activity measurements, overexpression of Xwnt-5A stimulates the phosphorylation of CamKII (Fig. 1 D). When the same blot was stripped and reprobed for total CamKII, comparable levels were observed (Fig. 1 D). After normalization to the total amount of loaded CamKII we found a 1.7-fold increase in CamKII phosphorylation (n = 3 experiments, S.E. = 0.15) upon injection of Xwnt-5A RNA in comparison to embryos injected with prolactin or Xwnt-8 RNAs. Similarly, Rfz-2 revealed a slight increase (1.3-fold increase, n = 2 experiments, S.E. = 0.04, data not shown) in phosphorylation of CamKII, whereas Rfz-1 did not. The relative increase in CamKII phosphorylation upon injection of Xwnt-5A or Rfz-2 RNA thus independently supports the kinase assays, and the conclusion that these Wnt and Frizzled homologs stimulate CamKII activity. In order to test whether the observed activation of CamKII by a subset of Wnt and Frizzled homologs is a rapid response to receptor activation, or a belated physiological reflection of this activation, we used inducible Frizzled/β2-AR chimeras (30.Liu X. Liu T. Slusarski D.C. Yang-Snyder J. Malbon C.C. Moon R.T. Wang H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 14383-14388Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar). This circumvented the need for purified active Wnts. These chimeras consist of the extracellular and transmembrane regions of the hamster β2-AR and the intracellular domains of either Rfz-2 or Rfz-1 (Fig. 2 A). We observed that Xenopus embryo cells expressing Rfz-2/β2-AR and treated with the agonist isoproterenol displayed activation of CamKII within 10 min (Fig. 2 B), without substantially greater activation at 30 min (data not shown). In contrast, treatment with the antagonist propranolol did not induce CamKII. The agonist-dependent activation was attributable to Rfz-2 and not other domains of the chimeric receptor since the Rfz-1/β2-AR chimera did not activate CamKII (Fig.2 B). As observed with native Rfz-2, the activation of CamKII by the RFz-2/β2-AR chimera upon treatment with agonist was sensitive to pertussis toxin (Fig. 2 B). We conclude that activation of CamKII by Rfz-2 occurs within minutes of receptor activation, and is d

Escherichia coli and other Gram-negative bacteria produce outer membrane vesicles during normal growth. Vesicles may contribute to bacterial pathogenicity by serving as vehicles for toxins to encounter host cells. Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) vesicles were isolated from culture supernatants and purified on velocity gradients, thereby removing any soluble proteins and contaminants from the crude preparation. Vesicle protein profiles were similar but not identical to outer membranes and differed between strains. Most vesicle proteins were resistant to dissociation, suggesting they were integral or internal. Thin layer chromatography revealed that major outer membrane lipid components are present in vesicles. Cytoplasmic membranes and cytosol were absent in vesicles; however, alkaline phosphatase and AcrA, periplasmic residents, were localized to vesicles. In addition, physiologically active heat-labile enterotoxin (LT) was associated with ETEC vesicles. LT activity correlated directly with the gradient peak of vesicles, suggesting specific association, but could be removed from vesicles under dissociating conditions. Further analysis revealed that LT is enriched in vesicles and is located both inside and on the exterior of vesicles. The distinct protein composition of ETEC vesicles and their ability to carry toxin may contribute to the pathogenicity of ETEC strains.

To study potential roles of plasma membrane-associated extracellular cathepsin B in tumor cell invasion and metastasis, we used the yeast two-hybrid system to screen for proteins that interact with human procathepsin B. The annexin II light chain (p11), one of the two subunits of the annexin II tetramer, was one of the proteins identified. We have confirmed that recombinant human procathepsin B interacts with p11 as well as with the annexin II tetramer in vitro. Furthermore, procathepsin B could interact with the annexin II tetramer in vivo as demonstrated by coimmunoprecipitation. Cathepsin B and the annexin II tetramer were shown by immunofluorescent staining to colocalize on the surface of human breast carcinoma and glioma cells. Taken together, our results indicate that the annexin II tetramer can serve as a binding protein for procathepsin B on the surface of tumor cells, an interaction that may facilitate tumor invasion and metastasis.

Escherichia coli expresses an inducible flavohemoglobin possessing robust NO dioxygenase activity. At 37 °C, the enzyme shows a maximal turnover number (V max) of 670 s−1 andK m values for NADH, NO, and O2 equal to 4.8, 0.28, and ∼100 μm, respectively. Individual reduction, ligand binding, and NO dioxygenation reactions were examined at 20 °C, where V max is ∼94 s−1. Reduction by NADH occurs in two steps. NADH reduces bound FAD with a rate constant of ∼15 μm−1s−1, and heme iron is reduced by FADH2 with a rate constant of 150 s−1. Dioxygen binds tightly to reduced flavohemoglobin, with association and dissociation rate constants equal to 38 μm−1 s−1and 0.44 s−1, respectively, and the oxygenated flavohemoglobin dioxygenates NO to form nitrate. NO also binds reversibly to reduced flavohemoglobin in competition with O2, dissociates slowly, and inhibits NO dioxygenase activity at [NO]/[O2] ratios of 1:100. Replacement of the heme pocket B10 tyrosine with phenylalanine increases the O2 dissociation rate constant ∼80-fold and reduces NO dioxygenase activity ∼30-fold, demonstrating the importance of the tyrosine hydroxyl for O2 affinity and NO scavenging activity. At 37 °C,V max/K m(NO) is 2,400 μm−1 s−1, demonstrating that the enzyme is extremely efficient at converting toxic NO into nitrate under physiological conditions. One-liter cultures were grown anoxically in medium containing 5 g of yeast extract and 10 g of tryptone per liter of 100 mm potassium phosphate, pH 7.0, 10 mmNaNO3, 20 mm glucose with 2 μmhemin and either tetracycline (12 μg/ml) or ampicillin (50 μg/ml). Cells were collected by centrifugation and were washed with chilled buffer A containing 5 mm NaN3. Azide was included to inhibit the loss of heme. Cells were lysed by sonication in 2 volumes of buffer A with ∼1 mg of deoxyribonuclease, and lysates were clarified by centrifugation. NOD was fractionated from extracts containing 12 mg/ml protein at 35–55% ammonium sulfate saturation at 4 °C. The precipitant was resuspended in 50 mm Tris-Cl, pH 8.0, 1 mm EDTA plus 5 mm NaN3(buffer B) and was dialyzed extensively at 4 °C against ∼100 volumes of the same buffer. The dialysate was then separated on a 2.5 × 18-cm DEAE-Sepharose (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) column in buffer B using a linear 50–400 mm NaCl gradient. Fractions having the highestA 410/A 280 ratios were pooled, concentrated, and separated on a 1 × 55-cm Superdex 75 column (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) in buffer B containing 50 mm NaCl. For smaller preparations from 2-liter cultures, flavoHbs were further separated on 1-ml Hi-Trap Mono Q columns (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) with a 50–200 mm NaCl gradient in buffer B. For larger preparations from 12-liter cultures, pooled Superdex 75 fractions were separated again on the DEAE-Sepharose as described above. FlavoHb fractions were concentrated and stored at 70 °C. FlavoHb yields were typically 2–5 mg/liter of culture. Sample purity was estimated from SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. For the wild-type and Phe(B10) substitution, purity was judged to be 95%, and for the B10 Glu and His mutants, purity was estimated at 80%. Where indicated, reconstitution with heme was achieved by incubating flavoHb with stoichiometric excesses of heme, dithiothreitol, and dithionite, and reactants were separated from flavoHb on a Sephadex G25 column in N2-purged buffer containing 50 mm Tris-Cl, pH 8.0, and 1 mmEDTA. All reactions were carried out in 0.1 m sodium phosphate, 0.3 mmEDTA at pH 7.0, and 20 °C. FlavoHbs were exposed to air on ice to allow complete oxidation as monitored at 404 nm. Vials containing flavoHbs were sealed and flushed with N2 for 10–20 min with gentle agitation to remove O2. An aliquot was removed with a syringe and diluted into anaerobic buffer. The resultant sample (3–4 μm heme) was injected in a Gibson-Dionex stainless steel stopped-flow apparatus and rapidly mixed with anaerobic buffer containing various amounts of NADH. The system was presoaked with concentrated deoxyhemoglobin to remove any residual O2. FAD reduction was followed at 460 nm, and heme iron reduction was monitored at 430 nm. Mathews A.J. Carver T.E. Olson J.S. Springer B.A. Egeberg K.D. Sligar S.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 3168-3176Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Solutions of the ferrous complexes contained ∼30–50 μm flavoHb and 300–600 μm NADH. Rebinding to flavoHb-Fe2+ was followed at either 430 nm (O2) or 436 nm (NO and CO). NO rebinding to flavoHb-Fe3+ was monitored at 419 nm in the absence of any reducing agent. To prepare flavoHb-Fe2+-O2 complexes, NADH was added to buffer equilibrated with various N2/O2 gas mixtures in a sealed 1-mm cuvette. FlavoHbs were injected into the cuvette, shaken, and immediately photolyzed. Time courses were recorded within 2 min of flavoHb injection, since the NADH oxidase activity of flavoHb rapidly depletes O2 and NADH at such high μm flavoHb concentrations, and soon either flavoHb-Fe2+ or flavoHb-Fe3+ is generated, depending upon which substrate is present in excess. As described under “Discussion,” the rate of O2 binding depends on the fraction of reduced iron present in the intermediate, which in turn almost certainly depends on the number of electrons present in the enzyme. Ca2+-dependent agonists, such as carbachol (CCh), stimulate epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) transactivation and mitogen-activated protein kinase activation in T84 intestinal epithelial cells. This pathway constitutes an antisecretory mechanism by which CCh-stimulated chloride secretion is limited. Here, we investigated mechanisms underlying CCh-stimulated epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) transactivation. Thapsigargin (TG, 2 μm) stimulated EGFR and extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) phosphorylation in T84 cells. Inhibition of either EGFR or ERK activation, with tyrphostin AG1478 (1 μm) and PD 98059 (20 μm), respectively, potentiated chloride secretory responses to TG, as measured by changes in short-circuit current (I sc) across T84 cells. CCh (100 μm) stimulated tyrosine phosphorylation and association of the Ca2+-dependent tyrosine kinase, PYK-2, with the EGFR, which was inhibited by the Ca2+ chelator, BAPTA (20 μm). The calmodulin inhibitor, fluphenazine (50 μm) inhibited CCh-stimulated PYK-2 association with the EGFR and phosphorylation of EGFR and ERK. CCh also induced tyrosine phosphorylation of p60 src and association of p60 src with both PYK-2 and the EGFR. The Src family kinase inhibitor, PP2 (20 nm-20 μm) attenuated CCh-stimulated EGFR and ERK phosphorylation and potentiated chloride secretory responses to CCh. We conclude that CCh-stimulated transactivation of the EGFR is mediated by a pathway involving elevations in intracellular Ca2+, calmodulin, PYK-2, and p60 src. This pathway represents a mechanism that limits CCh-stimulated chloride secretion across intestinal epithelia. This pathway constitutes an antisecretory mechanism by which CCh-stimulated chloride secretion is limited. Here, we investigated mechanisms underlying CCh-stimulated epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) transactivation. Thapsigargin (TG, 2 μm) stimulated EGFR and extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) phosphorylation in T84 cells. Inhibition of either EGFR or ERK activation, with tyrphostin AG1478 (1 μm) and PD 98059 (20 μm), respectively, potentiated chloride secretory responses to TG, as measured by changes in short-circuit current (I sc) across T84 cells. CCh (100 μm) stimulated tyrosine phosphorylation and association of the Ca2+-dependent tyrosine kinase, PYK-2, with the EGFR, which was inhibited by the Ca2+ chelator, BAPTA (20 μm). The calmodulin inhibitor, fluphenazine (50 μm) inhibited CCh-stimulated PYK-2 association with the EGFR and phosphorylation of EGFR and ERK. CCh also induced tyrosine phosphorylation of p60 src and association of p60 src with both PYK-2 and the EGFR. The Src family kinase inhibitor, PP2 (20 nm-20 μm) attenuated CCh-stimulated EGFR and ERK phosphorylation and potentiated chloride secretory responses to CCh. We conclude that CCh-stimulated transactivation of the EGFR is mediated by a pathway involving elevations in intracellular Ca2+, calmodulin, PYK-2, and p60 src. This pathway represents a mechanism that limits CCh-stimulated chloride secretion across intestinal epithelia. epidermal growth factor receptor carbachol G-protein-coupled receptor epidermal growth factor extracellular signal-regulated kinase 1,2-bis(O-aminophenoxy)ethane-N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid protein kinase C fluphenazine The secretion of fluid across the intestinal epithelium is a passive process driven by the osmotic gradients established by active transport of chloride. Chloride secretion is, in turn, governed by a wide array of neuroimmune mediators which, when released, typically alter epithelial function by binding to specific receptors on the epithelial surface. This results in the initiation of signaling cascades and elevation of intracellular levels of second messengers, such as cyclic adenosine 5′-monophosphate (cAMP) and calcium, that promote chloride, and consequently fluid, secretion. While increased fluid secretion is important in normal intestinal physiology, pathological conditions, such as inflammatory bowel disease, are characterized by increased neuroimmune mediator release which may give rise to excessive chloride and fluid secretion resulting in the onset of secretory diarrhea (1.Cooke H.J. News Physiol. Sci. 1998; 13: 269-274PubMed Google Scholar, 2.Montrose M.H. Keely S.J. Barrett K.E. Yamada T. Textbook of Gastroenterology. Third Ed. Lippencott, Williams and Wilkins, Philadelphia1999: 320-355Google Scholar). There is still little known of how chloride secretory responses may be limited in order to prevent excessive fluid loss from the body. In this regard, our laboratory has been investigating the role played by receptor tyrosine kinases, such as the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR),1 and their associated signaling pathways, in limiting calcium-dependent epithelial secretion. Treatment of colonic epithelial cells with epidermal growth factor (EGF) leads to inhibition of subsequent secretory responses elicited by calcium-dependent agonists, such as carbachol (CCh) (3.Uribe J.M. Gelbmann C.M. Traynor-Kaplan A.E. Barrett K.E. Am. J. Physiol. 1996; 271: C914-C922Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), an effect that is mediated by phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (4.Uribe J.M. Keely S.J. Traynor-Kaplan A.E. Barrett K.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 26588-26595Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). Furthermore, the EGFR may also be recruited by calcium-dependent signaling pathways where it appears to play an intrinsic role in limiting both the extent and duration of ongoing calcium-mediated secretory responses (5.Keely S.J. Uribe J.M. Barrett K.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 27111-27117Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar). Thus, stimulation of colonic epithelial cells with CCh, which acts via the Gq-coupled muscarinic M3 receptor (6.O'Malley K.E. Farrell C.B. O'Boyle K. Baird A.W. Eur. J. Pharmacol. 1995; 275: 83-89Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar, 7.Dickinson K.E. Frizzell R.A. Chandra Sekar M. Eur. J. Pharmacol. Mol. Pharmacol. 1992; 225: 291-298Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar), brings about transactivation of the EGFR with subsequent activation of the ERK isoforms of mitogen-activated protein kinase. Moreover, pharmacological inhibition of either the EGFR or ERK results in a potentiation of CCh-stimulated secretory responses. However, the molecular mechanisms by which CCh stimulates transactivation of the EGFR in T84 cells remained to be identified. Classically two major effector pathways are activated by GqPCR agonists such as CCh: stimulation of protein kinase C (PKC) and mobilization of intracellular Ca2+. Using the sesquiterpene lactone, thapsigargin, we have previously shown that elevations in intracellular Ca2+ alone are sufficient to stimulate epithelial chloride secretion (8.Kachintorn U. Vajanaphanich M. Traynor-Kaplan A.E. Dharmsathaphorn K. Barrett K.E. Br. J. Pharmacol. 1993; 109: 510-517Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). In contrast, stimulation of PKC with phorbol esters has a predominantly inhibitory effect on chloride secretion (9.Kachintorn U. Vajanaphanich M. Barrett K.E. Traynor-Kaplan A.E. Am. J. Physiol. 1993; 264: C671-C676Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). However, even though PKC stimulates ERK activation in T84 cells, it is unlikely to mediate the effects of CCh on EGFR and ERK activation since PKC inhibitors do not alter CCh-stimulated ERK phosphorylation (5.Keely S.J. Uribe J.M. Barrett K.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 27111-27117Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar). This suggests that the effects of CCh on EGFR and ERK activation are likely to be mediated by elevations in intracellular Ca2+. This has led to the idea that transactivation of the EGFR may be mediated by a pathway involving elevations in intracellular calcium, PYK-2, and p60 src. However, differences between various cell types in the details of this signaling cascade prompted us to examine to what extent this scenario can be extended to our chloride secretory model in T84colonic epithelial cells. Carbachol (Sigma), tyrphostin AG1478, PD 98059, PP2, and fluphenazine (Calbiochem, San Diego, CA), epidermal growth factor (Genzyme, Cambridge, MA), thapsigargin (LC Laboratories, Lexington, MA), mouse anti-human EGF receptor and mouse anti-phosphotyrosine antibodies (Upstate Biotechnology Inc., Lake Placid, NY), rabbit anti-p60 src antibodies (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, CA), mouse anti-PYK-2 (Transduction Laboratories, Lexington, KY), rabbit anti-phospho-ERK antibodies (New England Biolabs, MA), rabbit anti-phospho-PYK-2 antibodies (BIOSOURCE International, Camarillo, CA), and Tris glycine electrophoresis gels (Bio-Rad) were obtained from the sources noted. All other reagents were of analytical grade and obtained commercially. Methods for maintenance of T84cells in culture were as described previously (24.Weymer A. Huott P. Liu W. McRoberts J.A. Dharmsathaphorn K. J. Clin. Invest. 1985; 76: 1828-1836Crossref PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar). Briefly, T84 cells were grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's/F-12 medium (JRH, Lenexa, KS) supplemented with 5% newborn calf serum. For Ussing chamber/voltage clamp experiments, approximately 5 × 105 cells were seeded onto 12-mm Millicell transwell polycarbonate filters. For immunoprecipitation/Western blotting experiments, 106 cells were seeded onto 30-mm Millicell transwell polycarbonate filters. Cells seeded onto filters were cultured for 10–15 days prior to use. When grown on polycarbonate filters, T84 cells are known to acquire the polarized phenotype of native colonic epithelia. In accordance with the known distribution of their receptors on intestinal epithelia, CCh and EGF were added basolaterally in all experiments. Thapsigargin, which exerts its effects intracellularly at the level of the endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase, was added bilaterally. Monolayers of T84cells were mounted in Ussing chambers (window area = 0.6 cm2) and bathed in oxygenated (95% O2/5% CO2) Ringers' solution at 37 °C. The composition of the Ringers' solution was (in mm): 140 Na+, 5.2 K+, 1.2 Ca2+, 0.8 Mg2+, 120 Cl−, 25 HCO3−, 2.4 H2PO4−, 0.4 HPO42−, and 10 glucose. Monolayers were voltage-clamped to zero potential difference by the application of short-circuit current (I sc). Under these conditions, changes in I sc(ΔI sc) in response to agonists are wholly reflective of electrogenic chloride secretion (25.Cartwright C.A. McRoberts J.A. Mandel K.G. Dharmsathaphorn K. J. Clin. Invest. 1985; 76: 1837-1842Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar). T84cell monolayers were washed (2 times) with Ringers' solution, allowed to equilibrate for 30 min at 37 °C, and were then stimulated with agonists (± antagonists) as appropriate. The reaction was stopped by washing in ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline and the cells were lysed in ice-cold lysis buffer (1% Triton X-100, 1 μg/ml leupeptin, 1 μg/ml pepstatin, 1 μg/ml antipain, 100 μg/ml phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 1 mm Na+ vanadate, 1 mmsodium fluoride, and 1 mm EDTA in phosphate-buffered saline) for 45 min. Cells were then scraped into microcentrifuge tubes, spun at 12,000 rpm for 10 min and the pellet was discarded. Samples were assayed for protein content (Bio-Rad protein assay kit) and adjusted so that each sample contained an equal amount of protein. For immunoprecipitation studies, lysates were incubated with immunoprecipitating antibody, as per the manufacturer's instructions, for 1 h at 4 °C followed by another 1 h incubation at 4 °C with protein A-Sepharose. Lysates were then centrifuged for 3 min at 15,000 rpm and the supernatant was discarded. The pellets were washed in phosphate-buffered saline (3×) and resuspended in 2 × gel loading buffer (50 mm Tris, pH 6.8, 2% SDS, 200 mm dithiothreitol, 20% glycerol, 0.2% bromphenol blue) and boiled for 1 min prior to separation by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. Resolved proteins were transferred onto polyvinylidene membranes (NEN Life Science Products Inc., Boston, MA). After transfer the membrane was preblocked with a 1% solution of blocking buffer (Upstate Biotechnology Inc.) for 30 min followed by a 1-h incubation with the appropriate concentration of primary antibody in 1% blocking buffer. After washing (4 × 10 min) in Tris-buffered saline with 1% Tween (TBST), membranes were incubated for 30 min in horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody (anti-mouse or anti-rabbit IgG; Transduction Laboratories, Lexington, KY) in 1% blocking buffer. After washing in TBST (4 × 10 min), immunoreactive proteins were detected using an enhanced chemiluminescence detection kit (Roche Molecular Biochemicals, Indianapolis, IN). Densitometric analysis of Western blots was carried out using NIH Image software. All data are expressed as mean ± S.E. for a series of n experiments. Student's ttests or analysis of variance (ANOVA) with the Student-Newman-Keuls post-test were used to compare mean values as appropriate. pvalues <0.05 were considered to represent significant differences. We first set out to determine if elevations in intracellular Ca2+ are a sufficient stimulus for EGFR and ERK phosphorylation in T84 cells. Similar to our previous studies with CCh (5.Keely S.J. Uribe J.M. Barrett K.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 27111-27117Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar), treatment of T84 cells with TG (2 μm) rapidly stimulated tyrosine phosphorylation of the EGFR (Fig. 1 A) and both the ERK1 and ERK2 isoforms of mitogen-activated protein kinase (Fig.1 B). Furthermore, pretreatment of T84 cells with the EGFR kinase inhibitor, tyrphostin AG1478 (1 μm), partially reversed the effects of TG on ERK phosphorylation (Fig.1 C). In TG-stimulated cells ERK phosphorylation was 16.2 ± 5.4-fold over that in control, unstimulated cells compared with 6.8 ± 2.7-fold over control in tyrphostin-pretreated cells (n = 7; p < 0.05). Next, to determine if the EGFR and ERK are involved in regulation of TG-stimulated chloride secretion, we examined the effects of tyrphostin AG1478 and the ERK inhibitor, PD98059, on I scresponses to TG. Pretreatment of T84 cells with either inhibitor significantly potentiated subsequentI sc responses to TG (2 μm) (Fig.2). The maximal response to TG in tyrphostin (1 μm)-pretreated cells was 61.2 ± 9.1 μA/cm2 compared with 16.1 ± 1.6 μA/cm2 in control cells (n = 5;p < 0.005), while that in PD98059 (25 μm)-treated cells was 58.4 ± 8.5 compared with 29.5 ± 4.2 in paired controls (n = 6;p < 0.005). These data suggest that elevations in intracellular Ca2+ alone are sufficient to evoke antisecretory signaling via the EGFR and ERK in T84cells. In some cell types GPCR-mediated ERK activation is mediated by the Ca2+-dependent tyrosine kinase, PYK-2. Western blot studies employing an antibody specific for PYK-2 phosphorylated at the Y881 position revealed that CCh (100 μm) rapidly stimulated tyrosine phosphorylation of the enzyme in T84 cells (Fig.3 A). This was confirmed in experiments in which PYK-2 immunoprecipitates from CCh-stimulated cells were analyzed by Western blotting with antiphosphotyrosine (data not shown). Furthermore, analysis of anti-EGFR-immunoprecipitated cell lysates by Western blotting with anti-PYK-2 demonstrated that CCh also stimulates association of PYK-2 with the EGFR (Fig. 3 B). The kinetics of CCh-stimulated phosphorylation and association of PYK-2 with the EGFR were found temporally to precede those of CCh-stimulated EGFR and ERK phosphorylation (Fig. 3 C). In further experiments we sought to confirm that activation of PYK-2 occurs as a consequence of increases in intracellular Ca2+. Pretreatment of T84 cells with the intracellular Ca2+ chelator, BAPTA/AM (20μM), significantly reduced CCh-stimulated tyrosine phosphorylation of PYK-2 and abolished association of the enzyme with the EGFR (Fig. 3 D). BAPTA/AM also reduced CCh-stimulated EGFR phosphorylation to 41.7 ± 8.6% of that seen in control cells (n = 5; p< 0.01). In contrast, BAPTA/AM did not inhibit EGFR phosphorylation in response to EGF itself (data not shown). Calmodulin is a signaling intermediate which commonly mediates the effects of elevations in intracellular Ca2+ in many systems. We therefore examined the possibility that this protein may also mediate transactivation of the EGFR in response to CCh. T84 cells were pretreated wit the calmodulin inhibitor, fluphenazine (FPZ; 50 μm) prior to stimulation with CCh (100 μm). As shown in Fig.4, FPZ significantly reduced association of PYK-2 with the EGFR, and phosphorylation of both the EGFR and ERK in response to CCh. FPZ also inhibited CCh-stimulated tyrosine phosphorylation of PYK-2 to 47.9 ± 10.8% of that seen in controls (n = 6; p < 0.01). However, FPZ did not alter EGFR or ERK phosphorylation in response to EGF (100 ng/ml) itself (Fig. 4, inset). We next examined a potential role for p60 src in mediating CCh-stimulated EGFR and ERK activation in T84 cells. Immunoprecipitation/Western blot studies revealed that CCh (100 μm) rapidly stimulated tyrosine phosphorylation of p60 src (Fig.5 A). Interestingly, we also found that CCh increased the co-immunoprecipitation of an approximately 115-kDa tyrosine-phosphorylated protein, consistent with the molecular mass of PYK-2, with p60 src. Additional experiments, in which cell lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-p60 src and immunoprecipitated proteins were analyzed by Western blotting with anti-PYK-2, support the hypothesis that CCh stimulates association of PYK-2 with p60 src (Fig. 5 B). Furthermore, Western blot analysis of anti-EGFR immunoprecipitates with anti-p60 src demonstrate that CCh also stimulates association of p60 src with the EGFR in T84 cells (Fig.5 C). Next, to determine if p60 src might play a role in CCh-stimulated transactivation of the EGFR and ERK, we examined the effects of a Src family kinase inhibitor, PP2, on EGFR and ERK phosphorylation in response to CCh. Pretreatment of T84 cells with PP2 (200 nmto 20 μm) reduced both CCh-stimulated EGFR and ERK phosphorylation (Fig. 6,A-C) with the most prominent effect occurring at 20 μm. Of note, PP2 (20 μm) was without effect on either EGFR or ERK phosphorylation in response to EGF (Fig.6 D), further supporting the hypothesis that p60 src activation occurs upstream of the EGFR in response to CCh. Finally, we examined a possible role for p60 src in regulation of CCh-stimulated chloride secretion. Pretreatment of T84cells with PP2 (20 μm) significantly potentiated and prolonged subsequent I sc responses to CCh (100 μm) (Fig. 7). PeakI sc responses to CCh in control cells were 40.0 ± 5.2 μA/cm2 compared with 86.7 ± 13.6 μA/cm2 in PP2-pretreated cells (n = 6;p < 0.01). In separate experiments we found that PP2 also potentiated I sc responses to TG (2 μm). Control responses to TG were 23.3 ± 1.8 μA/cm2 compared with 90.5 ± 7.3 μA/cm2 in cells pretreated with PP2 (n = 4; p < 0.005). Tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α) induces reactive oxygen species (ROS) that serve as second messengers for intracellular signaling. Currently, precise roles of individual ROS in the actions of TNF-α remain to be elucidated. In this report, we investigated the roles of superoxide anion (O⨪2), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), and peroxynitrite (ONOO−) in TNF-α-triggered apoptosis of mesangial cells. Mesangial cells stimulated by TNF-α produced O⨪2 and underwent apoptosis. The apoptosis was inhibited by transfection with manganese superoxide dismutase or treatment with a pharmacological scavenger of O⨪2, Tiron. In contrast, although exogenous H2O2 induced apoptosis, TNF-α-triggered apoptosis was not affected either by transfection with catalase cDNA or by treatment with catalase protein or glutathione ethyl ester. Similarly, although ONOO− precursor SIN-1 induced apoptosis, treatment with a scavenger of ONOO−, uric acid, or an inhibitor of nitric oxide synthesis,N G-nitro-l-argininemethyl ester hydrochloride, did not affect the TNF-α-triggered apoptosis. Like TNF-α-induced apoptosis, treatment with a O⨪2-releasing agent, pyrogallol, induced typical apoptosis even in the concurrent presence of scavengers for H2O2 and ONOO−. These results suggested that, in mesangial cells, TNF-α induces apoptosis through selective ROS. O⨪2, but not H2O2 or ONOO−, was identified as the crucial mediator for the TNF-α-initiated, apoptotic pathway. Reactive oxygen species (ROS),1 including superoxide anion (O⨪2), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), hydroxyl radical (HO⋅), and peroxynitrite (ONOO−) are now thought of as signaling molecules that are mobilized in response to stimuli. ROS modulate Ca2+ signaling and protein phosphorylation events and, thereby, function as regulators for various biological processes, including gene expression, cell growth, differentiation, chemotaxis, and apoptosis (1.Suzuki Y.J. Forman H.J. Sevanian A. Free Radic. Biol. Med. 1997; 22: 269-285Crossref PubMed Scopus (1262) Google Scholar). ROS have been implicated in the signaling pathways initiated by tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α). Treatment of mammalian cells with TNF-α triggers generation of various ROS (2.Hennet T. Richter C. Peterhans E. Biochem. J. 1993; 289: 587-592Crossref PubMed Scopus (262) Google Scholar, 3.Garcia-Ruiz C. Colell A. Mari M. Morales A. Fernandez-Checa J.C. J. Biol. Cancer Res. 1989; 49: 1671-1675PubMed Google Scholar, 5.Phelps D.T. Ferro T.J. Higgins P.J. Shankar R. Parker D.M. Johnson A. Am. J. Physiol. 1995; 269: L551-L559PubMed Google Scholar). Pharmacological experiments revealed that the mitochondrial respiratory chain is the major source of TNF-α-induced ROS (6.Schulze-Osthoff K. Bakker A.C. Vanhaesebroeck B. Beyaert R. Jacob W.A. Fiers W. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 5317-5323Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 7.Schulze-Osthoff K. Beyaert R. Vandevoorde V. Haegeman G. Fiers W. Forman H.J. Sevanian A. Free Radic. Biol. Med. 1997; 22: 269-285Crossref PubMed Scopus (1262) Google Scholar, 8.Heller R.A. Kronke M. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 126: 5-9Crossref PubMed Scopus (402) Google Scholar). These data support the current hypothesis that ROS serve as crucial second messengers for TNF-α signaling. TNF-α induces apoptosis by engaging a cell surface receptor, TNF receptor 1 (TNFR1). Trimerization of TNFR1 by TNF-α induces association of the receptors' death domains. Subsequently, the adopter protein, namely, TNFR-associated death domain (TRADD) binds to the clustered receptor death domains through its own death domain. TRADD functions as a platform adapter that recruits Fas-associated death domain (FADD). FADD contains a death effector domain that binds to an analogous domain within procaspase-8. Upon recruitment by FADD, oligomerization of procaspase-8 drives its activation via self-cleavage and subsequently activates downstream effector caspases, leading to apoptosis (9.Ashkenazi A. Dixit V.M. Science. 1998; 281: 1305-1308Crossref PubMed Scopus (5168) Google Scholar). During this signaling process, ROS are supposed to play a critical role. It is based on the following evidence. (i) Stimulation of cells with TNF-α results in a rapid rise in the levels of intracellular ROS. (ii) Addition of ROS or depletion of endogenous antioxidants induces cellular death. (iii) TNF-α-triggered cytotoxicity is inhibited by antioxidants/ROS scavengers, including thioredoxin, N-acetylcysteine, pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate, and superoxide dismutase (SOD) (8.Heller R.A. Kronke M. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 126: 5-9Crossref PubMed Scopus (402) Google Scholar, 10.Buttke T.M. Sandstrom P.A. Immunol. Chem. 1998; 273: 13245-13254Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (523) Google Scholar). Oxygen normally accepts four electrons and is converted to water. In biological systems, however, partial reduction of oxygen occurs, resulting in the generation of cytotoxic ROS. That is, the sequential reduction of oxygen leads to the generation of O⨪2, H2O2, and OH⋅ (12.Jacobson M.D. Trend Biochem. Sci. 1996; 21: 83-86Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (730) Google Scholar). O⨪2 and H2O2 are thought to be the primary species generated. O⨪2 also rapidly reacts with nitric oxide (NO), yielding another reactive species, ONOO− (13.Szabo C. Ohshima H. Nitric Oxide. 1997; 1: 373-385Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar). In response to TNF-α, mammalian cells may produce O⨪2, H2O2, HO⋅, and ONOO−(2.Hennet T. Richter C. Peterhans E. Biochem. J. 1993; 289: 587-592Crossref PubMed Scopus (262) Google Scholar, 3.Garcia-Ruiz C. Colell A. Mari M. Morales A. Fernandez-Checa J.C. J. Biol. All of these ROS have the potential for triggering apoptosis (10.Buttke T.M. Sandstrom P.A. Immunol. Currently, however, the involvement of and precise roles for individual ROS in mediating the apoptotic process are not well understood. It is largely unknown which compounds are required or not required for the TNF-α-initiated apoptosis. In the present report, we dissect the roles of ROS in the TNF-α signaling. The present data suggest that O⨪2 mediates TNF-α-induced apoptosis and that conversion of O⨪2 to its downstream ROS, including H2O2, ONOO−, and HO⋅ is not required to mediate the apoptotic process in mesangial cells.
