The reaction was terminated by the addition of 10% acetic acid, and absorbance at 405 nm was read in the plate reader. Note that the α2M activity correlates with the remaining trypsin activity. α1PI was inactivated according to Johnson and Travis (17.Johnson D. Travis J. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 4022-4026Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar); 0.1 mg of human α1PI (Calbiochem) in 40 μl of 0.1 m Tris buffer, pH 8.8, was mixed with 10 μl of 80 mm N-chlorosuccinimide (Sigma) and incubated overnight. The excess of the reagent was removed using a centricon concentrator (Amicon). The remaining α1PI activity was less than 1 × 10−4of the original activity. α2M was inactivated by treating with 0.2 m methylamine in 50 mm Tris, pH 8.0, for 6 h at room temperature. After dialysis against 50 mm Tris, pH 8.0, the remaining activity was measured as described above, and the activity was not detected. After examining cell spreading, 50 μl of plasmin (5 mg/ml) in 0.1 mTris-HCl, pH 8.0, was overlaid on the fibrin gel, and the plates were shaken for 3 h at room temperature to dissolve the fibrin. The samples were then centrifuged for 1 min in a microcentrifuge at 14,000 rpm. Ten microliters of the supernatants, 40 μl of 50 mmTris-HCl, pH 8.0, and 10 μl of 1.6 mm S-2238 (Chromogenix) were mixed in the plate wells and incubated for 20 min. The reaction was terminated by the addition of 10% acetic acid, and absorbance at 405 nm was read. After observing the cell spreading, 25 μl of 25% SDS was overlaid on the fibrin gel. Most of the gels were dissolved after being shaken for 1 h. Insoluble materials, if any, were removed by centrifugation. The samples were run on 8% SDS-PAGE, and proteins were transferred to Immobilon-P membrane (Millipore Corp.). The membrane was blotted with anti-fibronectin antibody at 1:10,000 dilution, and the antigen was visualized with Renaissance Western blot chemiluminescence reagent (NEN Life Science Products). Band intensity was measured using a computer-assisted system. Purified proteins were run on 8% SDS-PAGE, transferred to Immobilon-P membrane, and stained briefly by Coomassie Brilliant Blue. The protein bands were cut out and subjected to sequence analysis according to Matsudaira (18.Matsudaira P. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 10035-10038Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). An Applied Biosystems Sequencer, model 477A, connected to Analyzer 120A was used for the analysis. The cell spreading activity was measured as described under “Materials and Methods” using smooth muscle cell line originating from the aorta of the newborn infant (11.Liaw L. Skinner M.P. Raines E.W. Ross R. Cheresh D.A. Schwartz S.M. Giachelli C.M. J. Clin. Invest. 1995; 95: 713-724Crossref PubMed Google Scholar,12.Perez-Reyes N. Halbert C.L. Smith P.P. Benditt E.P. McDougall J.K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 1224-1228Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar). The assay produced consistent results within 10% variations (see Figs. 1C, 4, and 6). In the presence of human plasma, the cells were well spread in 24 h in fibrin gel formed from recombinant fibrinogen (Fig. 1 A). In contrast, spreading is not observed in the plasma-free gel (Fig.1 B). The cells similarly spread regardless of the source of fibrinogen, recombinant fibrinogen, or plasma-derived fibrinogen. Fetal bovine serum, mature bovine plasma, and human serum also promote cell spreading in the same fashion (data not shown). With bovine fetal serum, the cells steadily spread in 6 h and slowly afterward in a dose-dependent manner (Fig. 1 C). In order to identify cell spreading factors present in plasma or serum, we tested several adhesion molecules if they promote the cell spreading in fibrin gel. The addition of vitronectin, fibronectin, or osteopontin to the fibrin gel has no effect on the cell spreading (Fig.1 D), although these factors were able to promote the cell spreading on plastic surfaces. Surprisingly, vitronectin, which has been shown to be a “serum spreading factor” for the cells spreading on glass or plastic surface (9.Preissner K.T. Blut. 1989; 59: 419-431Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 10.Tomasini B.R. Mosher D.F. Prog. Hemostasis Thromb. 1991; 10: 269-305PubMed Google Scholar), does not promote the cell spreading in fibrin gel. Other possible factors, thrombospondin-1 and PAI-1 also fail to promote the cell spreading. These results suggest that a novel factor(s) is present in plasma or serum to promote the vascular smooth muscle cell spreading in fibrin gel. We fractionated the plasma into six fractions by ammonium sulfate precipitation at 0–30, 30–40, 40–50, 50–60, 60–70, and >70% saturation. After the ammonium sulfate was removed by dialysis, these samples were assayed for the spreading activity as described under “Materials and Methods.” The activity was found in two fractions, 30–40 and 60–70%, indicating that at least two kinds of factors are present in the plasma. The factors present in these fractions were purified as detailed under “Materials and Methods.” The activity in the 60–70% ammonium sulfate fraction was purified by a combination of ion-exchange and hydrophobic interaction columns. Fig.2 A is the chromatographic pattern of a second phenyl-Sepharose column. The fractions at the descending edge of the major peak contain the high cell spreading activities. After trace contaminants were removed using the chelating column, the purified protein gave a single 58-kDa band on SDS-PAGE (Fig. 3 A). This protein has a single N-terminal sequence, LPENVTPEEQHKGTS, which is identical with bovine α1-proteinase inhibitor (α1PI) (19.Sinha D. Yang X. Emig F. Kirby E.P. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1994; 115: 387-391Crossref PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar). From the sequence and the observed molecular weight, the spreading factor in this fraction is identified as α1PI, a serine proteinase inhibitor. Bovine α1PI has an activity similar to human α1PI (or α1-antitrypsin) and has a homologousN-terminal sequence with α1ACT (19.Sinha D. Yang X. Emig F. Kirby E.P. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1994; 115: 387-391Crossref PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar). The purified α1PI inhibits 0.86 mol of trypsin/mol of protein.Figure 3SDS-PAGE of purified proteins. A, purified α1PI on 8% Laemmli gel.B, purified α2M on 5% Laemmli gel.M, molecular weight standard. Lane 1, nonreduced samples; lane 2, reduced samples.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) We speculated that the spreading factor in the 30–40% ammonium sulfate fraction is α2-macroglobulin (α2M) for two reasons. First, it could also be another proteinase inhibitor. Second, α2M precipitates at a low ammonium sulfate concentration while many other plasma proteinase inhibitors precipitate at high ammonium sulfate concentrations. Therefore, the chromatographic conditions previously developed for the purification of bovine α2M (20.Nagasawa S. Sugihara H. Han B.H. Suzuki T. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1970; 67: 809-819Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar) were adopted. It was purified by ion exchange and gel filtration column. Fig. 2 B shows the gel filtration pattern on Superose-6 column. The activity found in the first peak is further purified by Sepharose 4B column to remove trace contaminants. SDS-PAGE of the finally purified protein exhibits a typical gel migration pattern of the homotetramer of α2M. Double bands with high molecular weights are seen under the nonreduced condition, while a single band with 180 kDa is observed under reduced condition (Fig. 3 B). The commercial α2M migrates at the same positions as the purified protein under both reduced and nonreduced conditions. It is known that α2M is transformed to an inactive form by contact with ammonium ions at pH 8 or higher (21.Barrett A.J. Brown M.A. Sayers C.A. Biochem. J. 1979; 181: 401-418Crossref PubMed Scopus (413) Google Scholar). The inactive form migrates faster than the active form. The intensity of the two bands appeared on nonreduced gel (Fig. 3 B, lane 1) indicates that about one-quarter of the product is inactivated but three-quarters remain intact. The inactivation probably occurred during the ammonium sulfate fractionation, where α2M was exposed to pH 6.8. By titration with trypsin, the purified α2M inactivates 2.9 mol of trypsin/mol of protein, indicating that 73% of the protein is the active form. The sequence analysis gave a single N-terminal sequence, AVDGVEPQYM, which is identical with the reported bovine α2M sequence. To confirm the above results, we tested if the commercial preparations of α1PI, α1ACT, and α2M can promote the cell spreading. All three inhibitors from human source are able to promote the cell spreading in a dose-dependent manner (Fig. 4 A). To achieve 40% spreading, 2.3 × 10−6m of α1PI or α1ACT is required, whereas 9.2 × 10−8m of α2M is sufficient. Therefore, the cell spreading activity of α2M is 40-fold higher than α1PI and α1ACT. Because α2M has 4 reactive sites/mol, the cell spreading activity should be only 4 times higher than the others. Assuming that the commercial α2M is fully active, the activity of α2M is 10 times higher than the others. The cell spreading activities of PAI-1 and aprotinin inhibitor are null. Other serine proteinase inhibitors, α2-antiplasmin and C1 inhibitor, are also unable to promote the cell spreading (data not shown). To examine whether the entire cell spreading activity of human serum is attributed to the three proteinase inhibitors, we made a mixture that contains all three proteinase inhibitors at the normal serum concentrations, α1PI at 4.5 × 10−5m (2.5 mg/ml), α1ACT at 4.3 × 10−6m (0.25 mg/ml) and α2M at 3.5 × 10−6m (2.5 mg/ml) and tested its cell spreading activity. This mixture can promote the cell spreading with the same dose dependence as that obtained with human serum (Fig.4 B). As a control, albumin had no effect on the cell spreading at its serum concentration (40 mg/ml). We next deprived α1PI, α2M, or both from human serum by immunoprecipitation and tested the remaining cell spreading activity. Note that the positive control was able to induce fewer cell spreading in this experiment since the serum was diluted 500 times through the immunoprecipitation. 40% of the cell spreading activity is lost by the removal of each one of these inhibitors, and 95% of the activity is lost by the simultaneous removal of both proteins (Fig. 4 C). The remaining 5% activity is probably due to the presence of α1ACT. We could not determine the contribution of this inhibitor, because an appropriate antibody against α1ACT is not available. These and above results demonstrate that the three proteinase inhibitors, α1PI, α1ACT, and α2M, contribute together to the entire cell spreading activity of serum or plasma. First we tested whether these proteins function as adhesion molecules on plastic surfaces under the conditions as described before (22.Yee K.O. Rooney M.M. Giachelli C.M. Lord S.T. Schwartz S.M. Circ. Res. 1998; 83: 241-251Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). The smooth muscle cells do not attach to the surfaces coated with α1PI, α1ACT, or α2M. In contrast, the cells remain attached to the plastic surface coated with fibronectin or vitronectin (data not shown). These results indicate that these inhibitors do not function as adhesion molecules. We next studied whether the inhibitory activity of these proteins is required for the cell spreading in fibrin gel. α1PI was inactivated by treating withN-chlorosuccinimide, a selective oxidant of the essential methionine residue (17.Johnson D. Travis J. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 4022-4026Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The inhibitor activity is diminished to less than 1 × 10−4 of the original activity, and the cell spreading activity in fibrin gel is completely lost. To inactivate α2M, it was incubated with methylamine. The inhibitory activity of α2M was completely inactivated and the ability of the spreading activity also disappeared (data not shown). We could not perform the inactivation of α1ACT because an effective method is not found in the literature. Despite the lack of α1ACT data, these results clearly indicate that the proteinase inhibitory activity of these proteins is required for the cell spreading in fibrin gel. Because we use trypsin for harvesting the cells and thrombin for the fibrin gel formation, it is necessary to eliminate the possibility that these enzymes cause experimental artifacts. These possibilities can be ruled out from the following experiments. α1PI, α1ACT, or α2M is required for the cell spreading when the cell suspension is prepared by scrapping the cells from the cultured plates without using trypsin (data not shown). Two inhibitors specific to thrombin, antithrombin III andd-phenylalanyl-l-prolyl-l-arginine chloromethylketone, have no effect on the cell spreading. When these inhibitors are overlaid on fibrin gel, the cells do not spread, although the thrombin activity is completely inhibited. In the presence of serum or α1PI, the cell spreading activity is observed, and the thrombin activity is diminished to half of the original activity (data not shown). At this point, we hypothesized that a proteinase(s) secreted from the cells inhibits the cell spreading activity by destroying adhesion molecules essential to the cell spreading, and the proteinase inhibitors prevent their degradation. The smooth muscle cell line expresses a large number of integrins including α2, α3, α5, αv, β1, β3, and β5 (22.Yee K.O. Rooney M.M. Giachelli C.M. Lord S.T. Schwartz S.M. Circ. Res. 1998; 83: 241-251Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). Because two integrins, αvβ3 and α5β1, are known to be responsible for fibrin gel contraction (22.Yee K.O. Rooney M.M. Giachelli C.M. Lord S.T. Schwartz S.M. Circ. Res. 1998; 83: 241-251Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar), we tested if these two integrins are involved in the cell spreading in our system. Two anti-integrin antibodies, LM609 (αvβ3) and P4C10 (β1), completely inhibited the cell spreading when they were added to the fibrin gel together with α1PI, α1ACT, α2M, or calf serum (Fig.5 A). Similarly, when a polyclonal anti-fibronectin antibody (R790) was added to the fibrin gel at 0.1 mg/ml, the cell spreading diminished to 25–30% (Fig.5 B). However, the addition of the polyclonal anti-vitronectin antibody at 0.4 mg/ml had no effect on the cell spreading (data not shown). This concentration of the antibody was sufficient to inhibit the cell adhesion to the vitronectin-coated plastic plates (22.Yee K.O. Rooney M.M. Giachelli C.M. Lord S.T. Schwartz S.M. Circ. Res. 1998; 83: 241-251Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). Because no fibronectin is added to fibrin gel, fibronectin must be derived from the cells. In fact, we have shown that the same cell line produces fibronectin on their surfaces. 2Y. Ikari, K. Fujikawa, K. O. Yee, and S. M. Schwartz, unpublished observation. We then tested whether fibronectin is degraded in fibrin gel in the absence of the proteinase inhibitors or serum. After the cell spread in fibrin gel, the fate of fibronectin was examined by Western blot analysis as described under “Materials and Methods.” Since recombinant human fibrinogen is contaminated with hamster fibronectin from CHO cells, 3K. O. Yee, unpublished observation. we used fibronectin-free human fibrinogen. Therefore, bands shown in Fig.6 A are considered to be human fibronectin that is secreted from the cells. Without serum or the inhibitors, fibronectin was degraded into smaller fragments (Fig.6 A, lane 1), and the cells did not spread. α1PI, α1ACT, α2M, or serum prevents fibronectin degradation (lanes 2–5), and the cell spread normally in fibrin gel. In dose-response conditions, band intensities of intact fibronectin was linear to the concentration of α1PI (Fig. 6, Band C). The experiments with α1ACT or α2M showed the same linear pattern as α1PI (data not shown). Serum has long been recognized to contain molecules required for cell spreading. Vitronectin and other serum proteins that contain RGD sequences have been implicated as the factors to promote cell spreading (23.Barnes D.W. Silnutzer J. See C. Shaffer M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1983; 80: 1362-1366Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar, 24.Hayman E.G. Pierschbacher M.D. Ohgren Y. Ruoslahti E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1983; 80: 4003-4007Crossref PubMed Scopus (320) Google Scholar). From the data presented in this study, we propose a novel mechanism of the smooth muscle cell spreading in fibrin gel. In this mechanism, vitronectin does not appear to be critical to the cell spreading, whereas cell-derived fibronectin and integrins are required. The spreading is also dependent on extraneous serine proteinase inhibitors, which protect the degradation of fibronectin. If the proteinase inhibitors are not present, fibronectin is degraded by a proteinase(s) secreted from the cells. Therefore, the cells are not able to spread in fibrin gel. Is the cell spreading mechanism in fibrin matrix different from cell adhesion on a plastic surface? To clarify this question, we performed cell adhesion assays with or without proteinase inhibitors on a plastic surface coated with fibronectin, vitronectin, or fibrin. As previously reported (22.Yee K.O. Rooney M.M. Giachelli C.M. Lord S.T. Schwartz S.M. Circ. Res. 1998; 83: 241-251Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar), attachment was similar with or without the proteinase inhibitors on all surfaces at 1 h. However, at 24 h, almost all the cells had detached and looked round. In contrast, with proteinase inhibitors, the cells remained attached and spread at 24 h (data not shown). Short observation times in cell attachment studies have probably concealed this effect. Neutralization of cell-derived proteolytic enzyme(s) is necessary to keep matrices intact. This can be ignored within 1 h; however, it should be taken into account in cell attachment in vivo as well as in reactions over 24 h in vitro. Therefore, our data do not contradict the usual concept of vitronectin as an inducer of cell spreading. In vitro studies have shown multiple functions for vitronectin including cell adhesion, cytolysis, thrombosis, fibrinolysis, and inflammation (9.Preissner K.T. Blut. 1989; 59: 419-431Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 10.Tomasini B.R. Mosher D.F. Prog. Hemostasis Thromb. 1991; 10: 269-305PubMed Google Scholar). Vitronectin is obviously able to support cell adherence via the RGD motif that binds integrins, primarily αvβ3. Thus, RGD-containing proteins such as vitronectin and osteopontin have been implicated as critical molecules in several morphogenic processes (25.Giachelli C.M. Liaw L. Murry C.E. Schwartz S.M. Almeida M. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1995; 760: 109-126Crossref PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar). In contrast, knock-out studies of vitronectin or osteopontin have so far not shown any specific function for these proteins (26.Zheng X. Saunders T.L. Camper S.A. Samuelson L.C. Ginsburg D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 12426-12430Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar, 27.Liaw L. Birk D.E. Ballas C.B. Whitsitt J.S. Davidson J.M. Hogan B.L. J. Clin. Invest. 1998; 101: 1468-1478Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). A role of proteinase inhibitors in morphogenesis has been of interest in two areas, angiogenesis and mechanism of PAI-1 on cell adhesion. Montesano et al. (28.Montesano R. Pepper M.S. Vassalli J.D. Orci L. J. Cell. Physiol. 1987; 132: 509-516Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar) showed that angiogenesis could be modeled by treating endothelial cells with phorbol ester. Without proteinase inhibitors, these cells dissolve the fibrin matrix. In contrast, capillary-like sprouts form in the presence of Trasylol (aprotinin) or after depletion of plasminogen. The authors conclude that neutralization of excess proteolytic activity of plasmin may play an important permissive role in angiogenesis. In our model, cell spreading was not supported by aprotinin (Fig. 4 A) or plasminogen depletion (data not shown), probably because the responsible proteinase(s) is different from plasmin. PAI-1 is associated with the extracellular matrix and supports cell adhesion (29.Planus E. Barlovatz-Meimon G. Rogers R.A. Bonavaud S. Ingber D.E. Wang N. J. Cell Sci. 1997; 110: 1091-1098Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In contrast, PAI-1 can act as an inhibitor of cell adhesion by competing with vitronectin for binding to αvβ3 (30.Deng G. Curriden S.A. Wang S. Rosenberg S. Loskutoff D.J. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 134: 1563-1571Crossref PubMed Scopus (429) Google Scholar). However, these functions of PAI-1 do not depend on its antiproteinase activity. It is important to note that the proteinase inhibitors are ubiquitous. Proteinase inhibitors are the third major group of plasma proteins next to albumin and globulin. α1PI is a universal inhibitor of serine proteinases. Since lack of α1PI causes pulmonary emphysema and liver fibrosis, the physiological role of α1PI has been considered as an elastase inhibitor (31.Travis J. Salvesen G.S. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1983; 52: 655-709Crossref PubMed Scopus (1471) Google Scholar). α2M can block almost any type of proteinases. α2M is an ancient protein that is found in all vertebrates and even in nonvertebrates such as eels and crabs, suggesting that α2M is an essential protein in animals (32.Starkey P.M. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1983; 421: 112-118Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). While it is speculated that α2M is a carrier of transforming growth factor-β and other cytokines (33.Falcone D.J. McCaffrey T.A. Haimovitz-Friedman A. Garcia M. J. Cell. Physiol. 1993; 155: 595-605Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar) or as an agonist of α2M receptors (34.Howard G.C. Misra U.K. DeCamp D.L. Pizzo S.V. J. Clin. Invest. 1996; 97: 1193-1203Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar), no α2M genetic deficiency has been found in our species despite extensive screening of human plasma (31.Travis J. Salvesen G.S. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1983; 52: 655-709Crossref PubMed Scopus (1471) Google Scholar). Furthermore, α2M knock-out mice have no phenotype (35.Umans L. Serneels L. Overbergh L. Lorent K. Van Leuven F. Van den Berghe H. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 19778-19785Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). α1ACT is a chymotrypsin type serine proteinase inhibitor. α1ACT has been recognized as an acute phase protein, since serum concentration of α1ACT increases rapidly and dramatically after a variety of events including surgery, burn injury, and some types of cancer (31.Travis J. Salvesen G.S. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1983; 52: 655-709Crossref PubMed Scopus (1471) Google Scholar). Our data suggest that up-regulation of α1ACT may assist in wound repair by facilitating cell migration and proliferation. Furthermore, several cancers are known to express α1ACT, and the expression of α1ACT predicts a poor prognosis (36.Higashiyama M. Doi O. Yokouchi H. Kodama K. Nakamori S. Tateishi R. Cancer. 1995; 76: 1368-1376Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). Our data suggest that production of α1ACT may support cell attachment even where plasma proteinase inhibitor cannot reach. The attachment may support cell proliferation and resist apoptosis. Furthermore, not only human smooth muscle cells but also other cell lines, mouse fibroblasts, and rat smooth muscle cells, require proteinase inhibitors to spread in fibrin gel (data not shown). This spreading mechanism may be universal regardless of cell types. The alternative possibility is that the inhibitors block activation of proteinase-activated receptors (37.D'ery O. Corvera C.U. Steinhoff M. Bunnett N.W. Am. J. Physiol. 1998; 274: C1429-C1452Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). We tested thrombin receptor (proteinase-activated receptor-1) knock-out mouse fibroblasts for cell spreading. These cells still required proteinase inhibitors for cell spreading (data not shown). Other receptors not likely to be involved are the receptors for α2M (34.Howard G.C. Misra U.K. DeCamp D.L. Pizzo S.V. J. Clin. Invest. 1996; 97: 1193-1203Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 38.Ashcom J.D. Tiller S.E. Dickerson K. Cravens J.L. Argraves W.S. Strickland D.K. J. Cell Biol. 1990; 110: 1041-1048Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar, 39.Jensen P.H. Moestrup S.K. Gliemann J. FEBS Lett. 1989; 255: 275-280Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). These receptors recognize α2M complexed with proteinase or α2M treated with methylamine. However, receptor-recognizable α2M has no activity on cell spreading. The final obvious question is the identity of the target proteinase(s). Based on the specificity of α1PI and α1ACT, the major counterpart proteinase(s) should be chymotrypsin type serine proteinase(s), although higher activity of α2M than α1PI and α1ACT (Fig. 3 A) may suggest the existence of other minor active proteinases. Matrix metalloproteinases, well known cell-derived proteinases (40.Nagase H. Biol. Chem. 1997; 378: 151-160PubMed Google Scholar), are unlikely to be the major enzyme, because they are not serine proteinases and because an inhibitor of MMPs (GM 6001) (41.Bendeck M.P. Irvin C. Reidy M.A. Circ. Res. 1996; 78: 38-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (280) Google Scholar) had no effect on spreading (data not shown). Over 20 human chymotrypsin type serine proteinases have been identified (42.Perona J.J. Craik C.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 29987-29990Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar), including pancreatic chymotrypsin and prostate-specific antigen, which is widely used as a marker of prostate cancer. We detected a chymotrypsin type enzyme activity in the culture medium using chromogenic substrate (S-2586). However, biochemical purification has not been attempted, because a huge amount of cells is required. In conclusion, we have demonstrated that human smooth muscle cells spread in fibrin gel not only with the known spreading factors, but also with the proteinase inhibitors, α1PI, α1ACT, and α2M. These proteinase inhibitors may also control basic cell behavior and affect the progression of several pathological conditions. We are indebted to Brad McMullen (Department of Biochemistry, University of Washington) for performing the protein sequencing.

Iron release process of ovotransferrin N-lobe (N-oTf) to anion/chelators has been resolved using kinetic and mechanistic approach. The iron release kinetics of N-oTf were measured at the endosomal pH of 5.6 with three different anions such as nitrilotriacetate, pyrophosphate, and sulfate using stopped flow spectrofluorimetric method, all yielding clear biphasic progress curves. The two observed rate constants and the corresponding amplitudes obtained from the double exponential curve fit to the biphasic curves varied depending on the type and concentration of anions. Several possible models for the iron release kinetic mechanism were examined on the basis of a newly introduced quantitative equation. Results from the curve fitting analyses were consistent with a dual pathway mechanism that includes the competitive iron release from two different protein states, namely, X and Y, with the respective first order rate constants of K 1 andK 2 (X, domain closed holo N-oTf; Y, anion induced different conformer of holo N-oTf). The reversible interconversions of X to Y and Y to X are driven by the second order rate constant k 3 and the first order rate constant K 4, respectively. The obtained rate constants were greatly variable for the three anions depending on the synergistic or nonsynergistic nature. In the light of the anion-binding sites of N-oTf located crystallographically, the compatible mechanistic model that includes competitive anion binding to the iron coordination sites and to a specific anion site is suggested for the dual pathway iron release mechanism. N-lobe of human serum transferrin N-lobe of ovotransferrin C-terminal monoferric human serum transferrin N-terminal monoferric human serum transferrin nitrilotriacetate human serum transferrin 2-(N-morpholino)ethanesulfonic acid Transferrins are a class of bilobal proteins that bind, transport, and release various metals such as iron, aluminum, copper, and bismuth of which the key interest is to study the uptake and release of iron by transferrins because it is abundant and also plays a significant role in many biological processes (1.Aisen P. Listowsky I. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1980; 49: 357-393Crossref PubMed Scopus (938) Google Scholar, 2.Baker E.N. Adv. Inorg. Chem. 1994; 41: 389-463Crossref Scopus (214) Google Scholar). Each lobe of transferrin binds one Fe3+ ion in the interdomain cleft in presence of a synergistic anion (biologically, carbonate) with similar chemistry but with different affinity (3.Aisen P. Leibman A. Zweier J. J. Biol. Chem. 1978; 253: 1930-1937Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 4.Lin L.-N. Mason A.B. Woodworth R.C. Brandts J.F. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 1881-1888Crossref PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar). Although the main core of structure is similar in both the lobes (N and C), the chemistry is remarkably dissimilar toward the interaction of nonsynergistic anions (5.Oe H. Takahashi N. Doi E. Hirose M. J. Biochem. 1989; 106: 858-863Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar), disulfide bridges (6.Williams J. Elleman T.C. Kingston B. Wilkins A.G. Kuhin K.A. Eur. J. In this present complexity iron release kinetic mechanism of N-oTf was studied using three anions of different chemical nature: pyrophosphate, a chelator and nonsynergistic anion; NTA, a chelator and synergistic anion; and sulfate, a nonchelator and nonsynergistic anion. We have opted for isolated N-oTf because the solution and crystallographic structural details of iron binding and the intermediate complex of iron uptake are reported from this laboratory (15.Dewan J.C. Mikami B. Hirose M. Sacchettini J.C. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 11963-11968Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar, 31.Kurokawa H. Mikami B. Hirose M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6671-6676Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 32.Mizutani K. Yamashita H. Kurokawa H. Mikami B. Hirose M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 10190-10194Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar, 33.Mizutani, K., Yamashita, H., Mikami, B., and Hirose, M. (2000) Biochemistry, 39, in pressGoogle Scholar). The kinetic data was obtained using the stopped flow spectrofluorimetric method at the endosomal pH of 5.6 and single anion system at a time, for the iron release process of three different anions. Several kinetic models were analyzed by the newly introduced method to obtain the rate constants for the quantitative evaluation of the iron release kinetics. The crystallographic structure of nonsynergistic anion bound apo N-oTf (33.Mizutani, K., Yamashita, H., Mikami, B., and Hirose, M. (2000) Biochemistry, 39, in pressGoogle Scholar) along with the holo (15.Dewan J.C. Mikami B. Hirose M. Sacchettini J.C. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 11963-11968Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar) and iron uptake intermediate (32.Mizutani K. Yamashita H. Kurokawa H. Mikami B. Hirose M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 10190-10194Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar) structures of N-oTf were critically analyzed to derive a mechanistic model compatible with the dual pathway kinetic mechanism. N-oTf was prepared by the established procedure (34.Oe H. Doi E. Hirose M. J. Biochem. 1988; 103: 1066-1072Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). The protein concentration was measured in the apo form, and iron-bound holo form was prepared freshly in 100 mm Hepes, pH 7.4, using (Fe3+-NTA) complex as the iron donor and a large excess of bicarbonate as the synergistic anion to replace bound NTA. Holo N-oTf was then equilibrated to 50 mm Mes, pH 5.6, by dialysis, and the bound iron was confirmed spectrophotometrically to retain a 1:1 molar ratio with the protein. An N-oTf concentration of 5.5 μm was used in all the iron release experiments. Guaranteed grade of chemicals (pyrophosphoric acid from Wako Pure Chemicals; NTA and Na2SO4 from Nacalai Tesque), nitric acid-washed glassware and double distilled, deionized, and 40 μmfiltered water were used. Extreme care was taken to avoid any metal contamination or alteration of pH in all the solutions. All of the anion stock solutions were prepared freshly just before use in 50 mm Mes, and the pH was adjusted to 5.60 using NaOH and readjusted to 5.60 for minor changes, if any, upon dilution of anion stock solutions. The principle of nonradiative resonance energy transfer from excited aromatic chromophores to the visible charge transfer band of bound iron in transferrin (35.Lehrer S.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1969; 244: 3613-3617Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), which was successfully used to measure the iron release kinetics in transferrins, was adopted for our studies with minor modifications (12.Zak O. Aisen P. Crawley J.B. Joannou C.L. Patel K.J. Rafiq M. Evans R.W. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 14428-14434Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar,21.Egan T.J. Zak O. Aisen P. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 8162-8167Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). The kinetic data was precisely obtained by 1:1 sample mixing on a SX.18MV stopped flow reaction analyzer (Applied Photophysics Ltd., UK), which has the dead time of 4 ms. The excitation and emission wavelengths, 288 and 330 nm, respectively, were set on two different monochromators with a bandpass of 9.3 nm. A photomultiplier voltage of 600 mV with the reaction temperature of 30 ± 0.1 °C maintained using an external water bath and 50 mm Mes, pH 5.6, because the reaction buffer did not contribute to iron release from holo N-oTf in the absence of added anions used in the present study. The instrument conditions applied did not denature either apo or holo N-oTf even after 500 s of exposure, which was confirmed by the respective fluorescence emission properties. The data were collected using “oversampling mode,” which allows fast and accurate pickup and averaging of data points with improved signal-to-noise ratio over the extended time of measurements. A minimum of 1000 data points were collected per trace on a time scale of 0–500 s, and at least three identical traces were averaged for each anion concentration. The averaged traces were best fit using the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm to the following double exponential curve fit equation using the built-in software (version 4.36) on an Acorn Risc computer interfaced to the main instrument.Z(t)=1−A1 exp(−r1t)−A2 exp(−r2t)Equation 1 Z(t) is the fraction of iron-released (apo) form as detected by the change in fluorescence emission signal at time t, and A 1 andA 2 are the fractions of the fluorescence amplitudes (A 1 + A 2 = 1) for the observed rate constants r 1 andr 2 (r 1 >r 2), respectively. For the curve fit of raw data of all the three anions at different concentrations the normalized variance was between 6 × 10−7 and 6 × 10−8. The data derived from this primary analysis (r 1, r 2,A 1, and A 2) were plotted as a function of anion concentrations, and the curve fitting analyses by Equations Equation 3, Equation 4, Equation 5, Equation 6, Equation 7, Equation 8 (see “Results”) were carried out using the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm (KaleidaGraph, Synergy Software). Iron release kinetics of N-oTf were studied using three anions of different chemical nature: NTA, which can act both as a chelator and a synergistic anion; pyrophosphate, a strong nonsynergistic chelator anion; and sulfate, a simple nonsynergistic anion that can form a coordination complex with iron. In Fig.1 is shown a typical example of a clear biphasic progress curve of iron release from N-oTf to 100 mm NTA (A), 10 mm pyrophosphate (B), and 200 mm sulfate (C). The profiles can be demarcated by an initial rapid step followed by a slow hyperbolic step, both of which vary with the type and concentration of anion. For NTA the initial rapid process is significantly slow compared with the other two anions, and to emphasize the initial rapid phase the data within 20 s is shown as respective insets in Fig.1. The initial rapid process is very dominant in the case of pyrophosphate even below 5 mm concentrations but did not induce complete iron removal within the time frame of 500 s used in all the experiments. A similar observation was made in the case of sulfate, but in the case of NTA the initial rapid process was not clearly distinguishable below 10 mm concentration. For data analysis the anion concentrations that induce complete iron release within 500 s were considered. Sulfate and NTA below 20 mm and pyrophosphate below 10 mm did not induce complete iron removal. Biphasic progress curves of complete iron release from single iron-binding site of transferrin, either in the isolated N-lobe or in the selectively iron loaded N-lobe of full-length transferrin, have been observed for the first time with N-oTf. In Fig. 1, the solid line represents the best fit line to Equation 1 in all the three anion cases. The normalized variance for all the double exponential curve fits were in the order of 10−7 to 10−8, indicating the excellent fit. The two observed rate constants (r 1 and r 2) obtained from the curve fit are plotted as a function of NTA (A), pyrophosphate (B), and sulfate concentration (C) in Fig. 2. Only anion concentrations that yield complete iron removal were considered for analysis, and in the case of sulfate, higher concentrations were required to achieve complete iron removal. The larger rate constants (r 1) are increased almost linearly with anion concentration in all the three cases, and they are about one order lower in case of NTA compared with sulfate and pyrophosphate, at identical concentrations, although the values for pyrophosphate are more than twice compared with sulfate. The smaller rate constants (r 2) did not follow a linear relationship with anion concentration; instead, they follow an apparent hyperbolic pattern in all the three anion cases. The values are of the same order for NTA and sulfate but are of about five times smaller compared with pyrophosphate. The transcript cleavage factors GreA and GreB ofEscherichia coli are involved in the regulation of transcription elongation. The surface charge distribution analysis of their three-dimensional structures revealed that the N-terminal domains of GreA and GreB contain a small and large basic “patch,” respectively. To elucidate the functional role of basic patch, mutant Gre proteins were engineered in which the size and charge distribution of basic patch were modified and characterized biochemically. We found that Gre mutants lacking basic patch or carrying basic patch of decreased size bind to RNA polymerase and induce transcript cleavage reaction in minimally backtracked ternary elongation complex (TEC) with the same efficiency as the wild type factors. However, they exhibit substantially lower readthrough and cleavage activities toward extensively backtracked and arrested TECs and display decreased efficiency of photocross-linking to the RNA 3′-terminus. Unlike wild type factors, basic patch-less Gre mutants are unable to complement the thermosensitive phenotype of GreA–:GreB– E. coli strain. The large basic patch is required but not sufficient for the induction of GreB-type cleavage reaction and for the cleavage of arrested TECs. Our results demonstrate that the basic patch residues are not directly involved in the induction of transcript cleavage reaction and suggest that the primary role of basic patch is to anchor the nascent RNA in TEC. These interactions are essential for the readthrough and antiarrest activities of Gre factors and, apparently, for theirin vivo functions. The transcript cleavage factors GreA and GreB ofEscherichia coli are involved in the regulation of transcription elongation. The surface charge distribution analysis of their three-dimensional structures revealed that the N-terminal domains of GreA and GreB contain a small and large basic “patch,” respectively. The ubiquity of transcript cleavage factors in nature underscores their biological importance. Although gre and SII genes are not essential for cell viability, the deletion of these genes in Escherichia coli and S. cerevisiae renders them sensitive to certain growth conditions, such as elevated temperatures (10.Orlova M. Newlands J. Das A. Goldfarb A. Borukhov S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 4596-4600Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar) or the presence of 6-azauracil (20.Archambault J. Lacroute F. Ruet A. Friesen J.D. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1992; 12: 4142-4152Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar). The factor-stimulated cleavage of RNA occurs 2–18 bases upstream from the 3′-terminus, followed by dissociation of the 3′-proximal fragment from TEC. The 5′-proximal fragment of the transcript remains in TEC and can be extended in the presence of rNTPs. GreA induces hydrolysis of predominantly di- and trinucleotides (type A cleavage activity), whereas SII and GreB induce cleavage of 2–18-nucleotide-long RNA fragments (type B cleavage activity) (2.Borukhov S. A. 1995; 92: 4596-4600Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar), indicating that the same active center of RNAP is responsible for the cleavage reaction, as well as for pyrophosphorolysis and RNA synthesis reactions. The precise molecular mechanism by which Gre factors activate the endonucleolytic activity of RNAP is not known. The cleavage reaction mediated by Gre and SII factors is believed to be an integral part of the mechanism that allows RNAP to overcome obstacles encountered during elongation in vivo, such as pausing and arresting sites in the DNA sequences, nucleosomes, or DNA-binding proteins and drugs (6, reviewed in Ref. 24.Uptain S.M. Kane C.M. Chamberlin M.J. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1997; 66: 117-172Crossref PubMed Scopus (399) Google Scholar). The charge distribution analysis of three-dimensional structures revealed a cluster of positively charged residues on NTD of GreA and GreB that form a distinct structural feature, described as basic “patch,” on the side of the protein that is presumed to face RNAP in TEC. The basic patch residues of all known GreA and GreB molecules are highly conserved (Fig. 1). The photocross-linking experiments performed on various TECs have demonstrated that the 3′-terminus of RNA is located in the immediate vicinity of basic patch on both Gre proteins (33.Stebbins C.E. Borukhov S. Orlova M. Polyakov A. Goldfarb A. Darst S.A. Nature. 1995; 373: 636-640Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar, 34.Koulich D. Orlova M. Malhotra A. Sali A. Darst S.A. Goldfarb A. Borukhov S. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 7201-7210Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar), implicating basic patch in the functional interaction of Gre proteins with RNA in TEC. Additionally, the lengths of basic patch on GreA and GreB, ∼7 and ∼35 Å, respectively, were noted to correlate with the maximum lengths of RNA fragments that can be excised from TEC in the presence of Gre factors: 2–3 nucleotides for GreA and up to 18 nucleotides for GreB. Finally, it was observed that in the absence of factors, the nucleolytic activity of RNAP can be stimulated at a mildly alkaline pH, which mimics the effect of GreA (at pH 8.5–9.5) and GreB (at pH above 10.0) (10.Orlova M. Newlands J. Das A. Goldfarb A. Borukhov S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 4596-4600Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar). Based on these observations, two alternative hypotheses were proposed for the role of basic patch in Gre function: first, the basic patch residues increase the local pH near the active site of RNAP and directly affect its catalytic properties; second, they bind the nascent RNA by electrostatic interaction, thereby facilitating the cleavage reaction and determining the size of cleavage product. To test these hypotheses, we introduced a series of mutations in Gre proteins that would result in altered size and charge distribution of basic patch. The functional properties of mutant proteins were analyzed in vivo and in vitro. The results that we present rule out the first hypothesis and support the second, suggesting that the role of basic patch is to bind the 3′-terminal portion of the nascent RNA and to maintain it in proper orientation in TEC. Based on our results, we conclude that Gre-RNA interactions mediated through basic patch are essential for the readthrough and antiarrest functions of Gre factorsin vitro and for their activity in vivo. A mutant F1-ATPase α3β3γ subcomplex from the thermophilicBacillus PS3 was constructed, in which 111 amino acid residues (Val92 to Phe202) from the central region of the γ subunit were replaced by the 148 amino acid residues of the homologous region from spinach chloroplast F1-ATPase γ subunit, including the regulatory stretch, and were designated as α3β3γ(TCT)(Thermophilic-Chloroplast-Thermophilic). By the insertion of this regulatory region into the γ subunit of thermophilic F1, we could confer the thiol modulation property to the thermophilic α3β3γ subcomplex. The overexpressed α3β3γ(TCT) was easily purified in large scale, and the ATP hydrolyzing activity of the obtained complex was shown to increase up to 3-fold upon treatment with chloroplast thioredoxin-f and dithiothreitol. No loss of thermostability compared with the wild type subcomplex was found, and activation by dithiothreitol was functional at temperatures up to 80 °C. α3β3γ(TCT) was inhibited by the ε subunit from chloroplast F1-ATPase but not by the one from the thermophilic F1-ATPase, indicating that the introduced amino acid residues from chloroplast F1-γ subunit are important for functional interaction with the ε subunit. Leslie A.G.W. Lutter R. Walker J.E. Nature. 1994; 370: 621-628Crossref PubMed Scopus (2752) Google Scholar). The molecular structure of the F0F1-ATP synthase of chloroplasts may be basically the same as those of other F0F1, but this enzyme has a unique regulation system. The activity of chloroplast F0F1 and F1 (CF1) is strongly regulated by the reduction and the oxidation of a disulfide bridge in the γ subunit formed between the two cysteines Cys199 and Cys205(spinach chloroplast) (18.Miki J. Maeda M. Mukohata Y. Futai M. FEBS Lett. 1988; 232: 221-226Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar); this regulation system is called thiol modulation (19.Nalin C.M. McCarty R.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 7275-7280Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Reduction of the disulfide bond elicits the latent ATP hydrolyzing activity of the isolated CF1. In vitro reduction can be achieved by dithiothreitol (DTT) or other dithiols, but the natural reductant is reduced thioredoxin-f(Trx-f) (20.Schwarz O. Schürmann P. Strotmann H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16924-16927Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar, 21.Stumpp M.T. Motohashi K. Hisabori T. Biochem. J. 1999; 341: 157-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 22.Creczynski-Pasa T.B. Graber P. FEBS Lett. 1994; 350: 195-198Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). Introduction of nine amino acids comprising the regulatory sequence into the cyanobacterial γ subunit induced thiol modulation in Synechocystis (23.Werner-Grune S. Gunkel D. Schümann J. Strotmann H. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1994; 244: 144-150Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, 24.Krenn B.E. Ardewijn P. Van Walraven H.S. Werner-Grüne S. Strotmann H. Biochem. Soc. Trans. 1995; 23: 757-760Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). Conversely, replacement of the two cysteines by serines in γ subunit of CF0CF1 from Chlamydomonas reinhardtii (25.Ross S.A. Zhang M.X. Selman B.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 9813-9818Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 26.Ross S.A. Zhang M.X. Selman B.R. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1996; 28: 49-57Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar) resulted in a non-modulated enzyme. However, due to the lack of suitable overexpression systems for the subunits of CF1 and because of its insufficient ability for the reconstitution of the complete enzyme complex, little information is available about the details of this regulation mechanism. Recently we have succeeded in the reconstitution of a chimeric complex from recombinant α and β subunits of F1 of the thermophilicBacillus PS3 (TF1) and the recombinant γ subunit from spinach CF1 (27.Hisabori T. Kato Y. Motohashi K. Kroth-Pancic P. Strotmann H. Amano T. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 1158-1165Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). The resulting chimeric α3β3γ complex, which had substantial ATPase activity, was clearly regulated by the disulfide/dithiol state of the two regulatory cysteine residues. We could demonstrate the importance of the region around the disulfide bridge of γ subunit for the regulatory interaction with ε subunit which is known to inhibit activity (28.Hisabori T. Motohashi K. Kroth P. Strotmann H. Amano T. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 15901-15905Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). However, stability of this chimeric complex was still lower than that of wild type thermophilic α3β3γ, and large scale preparation was difficult. In order to understand the molecular mechanism of thiol regulation, we engineered a chimeric α3β3γ subcomplex of TF1 in which the central half of the γ subunit was replaced by the equivalent part of the γ subunit from CF1including the regulatory cysteines (Fig.1). The remaining parts derived from the TF1-γ subunit mainly consists of the N-terminal and C-terminal α-helices forming the coiled-coil and a small additional α-helix. The chimeric α3β3γ subcomplex was successfully overexpressed in Escherichia coli and purified as an active ATPase. Then we investigated the enzymatic property of this complex under reduced and oxidized conditions. Restriction enzymes were purchased from Toyobo Co., Tokyo, Japan. Acta. 1973; 320: 635-647Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar,30.Grubmeyer C. Penefsky H.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 3718-3727Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Plasmid amplification was carried out with E. coli strain JM 109, and single-stranded uracil-containing DNA was obtained from E. coli strain CJ 236, and for protein overexpression E. coli strain JM 103 ΔuncB-D was used. Kinosita Jr., K. Nature. 1997; 388: 299-302Crossref Scopus (1966) Google Scholar), was cloned into the multi-cloning site of the M13mp18 vector, and single-stranded uracil-containing DNA was obtained by the method of Ref. 31.Kunkel T.A. Bebenk K. McClary J. Methods Enzymol. 1991; 204: 125-139Crossref PubMed Scopus (633) Google Scholar. Bebenk K. McClary J. Methods Enzymol. 1991; 204: 125-139Crossref PubMed Scopus (633) Google Scholar) using the primers 5′-CACGAGGCGCAGCACGTTCGAATTGTACGCGCCAGC and 5′-TTCTTCTTGCGACGGTTCGAATTCGTACACCGTGCG. Then the DNA fragment coding the deduced γ subunit was cut out with the restriction enzymesNheI and BglII and cloned into the equivalent position between the genes for the α and β subunits on the pkkHisCys5 vector. A fragment of spinach chloroplast DNA coding for amino acid residues Leu96-Phe243 of the γ subunit of CF1 was amplified by the polymerase chain reaction method using the phosphorylated primers 5′-CGGGATCCCGTTAGAAGTTGCTGAAGAAGGCTGAGTCTAGG and 5′-CGGGATCCCGTTCGAATTCCAGAATTGGGGAAAATGCTGG with the vector containing the gene for the γ subunit of spinach CF1 (27.Hisabori T. Kato Y. Motohashi K. Kroth-Pancic P. Strotmann H. Amano T. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 1158-1165Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar) as a template. The obtained DNA fragment was inserted by blunt-end ligation into pBluescript vector, which was previously digested withSmaI. Then the vector was digested with NspV to obtain a cohesive-end DNA fragment. Finally the above described pkkHisCys5 vector with two introduced NspV sites was digested with NspV and ligated with the cohesive-end DNA fragment to obtain the expression plasmid for α3β3γ(TCT) (pkkTCT vector). The correct orientation of the DNA fragment inserted into pkkTCT was confirmed by digestion with NheI and AflII. pkkTCT was transformed into E. coli JM 103 strain, cultivated on LB medium agar plates containing 100 μg/ml ampicillin, and then inoculated into the liquid culture. A 2-liter liquid culture in the same medium was harvested after 9 h cultivation. Cells were collected by centrifugation and disrupted by sonication. The supernatant was directly applied to a nickel-NTA (nitrilotriacetic acid) superflow column (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany) equilibrated with 50 mm MOPS-KOH, pH 7.0, 100 mm KCl, 5 mm MgCl2, and 10 mm imidazole. The column was washed with the same buffer containing 25 mmimidazole and then the enzyme was eluted with the same buffer containing 250 mm imidazole. The recombinant α3β3γ subcomplex of TF1 containing a histidine tag on the N terminus of the β subunit and the substitution of Ser106 of the γ subunit to Cys (α3β3γ (β-His, γS106C)) was expressed by using the pkkHisCys5 vector and purified by the method described (11.Boyer P.D. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1098: 215-250Crossref Scopus (924) Google Scholar). ε subunit of TF1 was overexpressed in E. coli and isolated as described (32.Kato Y. Matsui T. Tanaka N. Muneyuki E. Hisabori T. Yoshida M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 24906-24912Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). The recombinant ε subunit of CF1 was expressed as an inclusion body and purified (27.Hisabori T. Kato Y. Motohashi K. Kroth-Pancic P. Strotmann H. Amano T. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 1158-1165Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). Prior to use, the folded ε subunit of CF1 was prepared as follows: the inclusion body was solved with 8 m urea, 50 mmTris-Cl, pH 8.0, 1 mm EDTA, and 0.5 mm DTT and dialyzed against 50 mm MOPS-KOH, pH 7.0, 100 mmKCl, and 5 mm MgCl2 for 6 h. Spinach chloroplast Trx-f was overexpressed in E. coli and isolated as described (21.Stumpp M.T. Motohashi K. Hisabori T. Biochem. J. 1999; 341: 157-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). The concentration of the purified Trx-fwas determined by the measurement of the absorbance at 278 nm using the published molar absorption coefficient value of 16,830m−1·cm−1 (33.Schürmann P. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 252: 274-283Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). ATP hydrolysis activity was measured in the presence of an ATP regenerating system (34.Stiggal D.L. Galante Y.M. Hatefi Y. Methods Enzymol. 1979; 55: 308-315Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar) with a spectrophotometer model U-3100 (Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan) equipped with a stirrer. The reaction mixture containing 50 mm MOPS-KOH, 100 mm KCl, 5 mm MgCl2, 2 mm phosphoenolpyruvate, 2 mm ATP, 50 μg/ml pyruvate kinase, 50 μg/ml lactate dehydrogenase, and 0.2 mm NADH was used. After a base line was monitored for 1–2 min, the reaction was initiated by the addition of 5–10 μg of α3β3γ(TCT), and the activity was measured by monitoring the decrease of NADH absorption at 340 nm at 25 °C. In the case where the ATP regenerating system was not applicable, the activity was measured by quantifying the amount of produced phosphate (35.Hisabori T. Muneyuki E. Odaka M. Yokoyama K. Mochizuki K. Yoshida M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4551-4556Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). 80 μl of 50 mm MOPS-KOH, pH 7.0, 100 mmKCl, 5 mm MgCl2, and 2 mm ATP were incubated in a water bath for 2 min, and then the reaction was started by the addition of 20 μl (2 μg) of α3β3γ(TCT). After 2 min, the reaction was quenched by the addition of 100 μl of 2.4% (w/v) trichloroacetic acid. The reaction was carried out at 25 °C unless stated otherwise. α3β3γ(TCT) or α3β3γ (β-His, γS106C) were mixed with the ε subunit of CF1 or TF1 and incubated for 1 h at room temperature. The mixture was then directly applied to the ATP hydrolysis assay using an ATP regenerating system as described above. α3β3γ(TCT)was oxidized with 50 μm CuCl2 or reduced with 15 mm DTT for 1 h at 30 °C. DTT in the sample was removed by an HPLC gel filtration column (TSK 3000SWXL, Tosoh Co., Tokyo, Japan) equilibrated with 50 mm MOPS-KOH, pH 7.0, 100 mm KCl, and 5 mm MgCl2because DTT directly affected the following quantitative measurement of nucleotides. This step also reduced the amount of intrinsically bound nucleotides from 0.8 mol ADP/mol α3β3γ(TCT) to <0.1 mol ADP/mol α3β3γ(TCT). Each of the complexes was diluted to a protein concentration of 700 nm. A 50-μl aliquot was preincubated in a 25 °C water bath and then mixed with the same volume of 150 nm TNP-ATP. At the indicated period the reaction was terminated by addition of 5 μl of 24% (w/v) trichloroacetic acid. The amounts of TNP-ATP and TNP-ADP were determined by reversed-phase HPLC (35.Hisabori T. Muneyuki E. Odaka M. Yokoyama K. Mochizuki K. Yoshida M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4551-4556Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In case of chase acceleration experiments, 10 μl of 100 μm ATP was added instead of trichloroacetic acid and incubated for further 10 s. Then the reaction was stopped by the addition of trichloroacetic acid as stated above. Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis in the presence of SDS was performed according to Laemmli (36.Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (207180) Google Scholar). Protein bands were visualized by the staining with Coomassie Brilliant Blue R-250. α3β3γ(TCT)was overexpressed in E. coli JM 103 and purified by Ni-NTA affinity chromatography. The purity of the protein and the occurrence of the individual subunits in the complex were confirmed by SDS-gel electrophoresis (Fig. 2). The yield of α3β3γ(TCT) complex was about 80 mg of protein from a 2-liter E. coli culture, comparable to the yield of wild type α3β3γ (7.Matsui T. Yoshida M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1995; 1231: 139-146Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar) or α3β3γ (β-His, γS106C) (14.Noji H. Yasuda R. Yoshida M. Kinosita Jr., K. Nature. 1997; 388: 299-302Crossref Scopus (1966) Google Scholar). The molecular mass of the γ subunit in the α3β3γ(TCT) complex was about 35 kDa, clearly larger than the γ subunit of α3β3γ (β-His, γS106C) but very similar to the γ subunit of CF1 (Fig. 2), indicating the successful expression and the formation of the complex with the mutant γ subunit. The activity of ATP hydrolysis catalyzed by the purified α3β3γ(TCT) was measured spectrophotometrically by the pyruvate kinase/lactate dehydrogenase assay that provides continuous regeneration of ATP. Upon addition of oxidized and reduced α3β3γ(TCT) to the reaction mixture, ATP hydrolysis proceeded in a linear manner for at least 10 min without time-dependent inactivation (Fig.3 A), but the rates were different as follows: α3β3γ(TCT) was clearly activated by preincubation with DTT. When DTT alone was used for reduction, up to 2-fold activation was obtained (Fig. 3, Aand B). Activation was saturated at 15 mm DTT (Fig. 3 B). Extension of the preincubation time for more than 1 h did not significantly increase activation. Interestingly, the activation was higher if reduction was carried out with a combination of DTT and Trx-f (Fig. 3, A and B). When ATP hydrolysis reaction was initiated by addition of oxidized α3β3γ(TCT) and 15 mm DTT plus 500 nm Trx-f (final concentration) was added to the reaction mixture after 5 min, remarkable activation could be observed within several minutes (Fig.3 A, inset). The concentration of Trx-ffor half-maximal activation was about 200 nm (Fig.3 B, inset), considerably lower than that for authentic CF1, which was more than 1 μm (21.Stumpp M.T. Motohashi K. Hisabori T. Biochem. J. 1999; 341: 157-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). The specific activity of α3β3γ(TCT) in the oxidized state was 1.0–1.2 units/mg, and upon reduction with 15 mmDTT it increased to 2.2–2.6 units/mg, and with 15 mm DTT plus 500 nm Trx-f 3.0–3.3 units/mg were measured. Quantification of thiol groups indicated additional 1.6–1.9 mol of SH/mol of α3β3γ(TCT)after reduction with 15 mm DTT and additional 1.7–2.0 mol of SH/mol of α3β3γ(TCT) after reduction with 15 mm DTT plus 500 nmTrx-f. The specific activity of α3β3γ(TCT) in the fully reduced state under the reaction conditions above (pH 7.0) was comparable to that of α3β3γ (β-His, γS106C) under the same conditions (4.5 units/mg). The pH optimum was between 8.5 and 9.0, similar to the values reported for wild type α3β3γ (7.Matsui T. Yoshida M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1995; 1231: 139-146Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar), for TF1 (37.Yoshida M. Sone N. Hirata H. Kagawa Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1975; 250: 7910-7916Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and for CF1 (38.Sakurai H. Shinohara K. Hisabori T. Shinohara K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1981; 90: 95-102Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). The optimum temperature of the ATPase activity of oxidized and reduced α3β3γ(TCT) was at 70 °C, the same as that of α3β3γ (β-His, γS106C) (Fig. 4) and comparable to the values reported for wild type TF1 and α3β3γ (7.Matsui T. Yoshida M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1995; 1231: 139-146Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar). The ratio between the activities of oxidized and reduced α3β3γ(TCT) did not change significantly over the whole temperature range investigated. The effect of the inhibitory ε subunit of CF1 and that of TF1 on α3β3γ(TCT) was investigated (Fig. 5 A). ATPase activity of α3β3γ(TCT) in its oxidized state was inhibited to 50–60% by the ε subunit of CF1. Interestingly, α3β3γ(TCT) in its reduced state was nearly insensitive to the CF1-ε subunit, resulting in about a 4-fold higher activity compared with α3β3γ(TCT) in the oxidized state in the presence of the CF1-ε subunit. As reported previously, neither the CF1-ε subunit nor the TF1-ε subunit had any significant effect on the activity of α3β3γ (β-His, γS106C) when the ATP concentration was relatively high (32.Kato Y. Matsui T. Tanaka N. Muneyuki E. Hisabori T. Yoshida M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 24906-24912Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). However, a slight but significant increase of activity was observed upon incubation of oxidized α3β3γ(TCT) with the TF1-ε subunit (Fig. 5 A). Again, this effect was less pronounced for α3β3γ(TCT) in the reduced form. To clarify the cause of the weakly stimulating effect of the ε subunit of TF1 on ATPase activity of α3β3γ(TCT), we examined its binding to the complex. After incubation with ε subunit of TF1, the complex was separated from unbound ε subunit by gel filtration HPLC. The α3β3γ(TCT) fraction was then applied to SDS-PAGE (Fig. 5 B). α3β3γ(TCT) in the oxidized state as well as in the reduced state could bind the ε subunit of TF1 in an approximately stoichiometric ratio, comparable to α3β3γ (β-His, γS106C) under identical conditions. When a substoichiometric molar ratio of TNP-ATP was added to the oxidized or reduced α3β3γ(TCT) complexes, the ATP analogue was slowly hydrolyzed. With both complexes it took 20 s to hydrolyze 50% of added TNP-ATP (Fig.6). An interesting difference was observed upon the addition of chase ATP. Whereas hydrolysis of TNP-ATP by reduced α3β3γ(TCT) was greatly accelerated by ATP, comparable to wild type α3β3γ (32.Kato Y. Matsui T. Tanaka N. Muneyuki E. Hisabori T. Yoshida M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 24906-24912Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar) and α3β3γ (βI389C) (39.Tsunoda S.P. Muneyuki E. Amano T. Yoshida M. Noji H. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 5701-5706Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar), chase promotion was obviously lower in the case of the oxidized α3β3γ(TCT). In this study, an expression plasmid for an α3β3γ subcomplex of TF1containing a TF1/CF1 chimeric γ subunit (α3β3γ(TCT)) was constructed, and the desired protein complex was successfully overexpressed and purified with a yield comparable to those of wild type α3β3γ (7.Matsui T. Yoshida M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1995; 1231: 139-146Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar) or α3β3γ (β-His, γS106C) (14.Noji H. Yasuda R. Yoshida M. Kinosita Jr., K. Nature. 1997; 388: 299-302Crossref Scopus (1966) Google Scholar). This proves that combining two halves of γ subunits from different organisms and the insertion of additional amino acid residues from the γ subunit of CF1 into the central part of the γ subunit of TF1 are no major obstacles for biosynthesis and in vivo stability of this protein complex in the employed expression system. Thus, although the homology between the transferred part of CF1-γ subunit and the replaced part of the TF1-γ subunit was only about 15% on the amino acid level, proper folding of the γ subunit and insertion into the α3β3 hexagon appears to be unaffected. This is consistent with a recently published intermediate-resolution x-ray structure of E. coli F1, which indicated that four α-helices, thought to be comprised by the central amino acid residues of the γ subunit (roughly E. coli F1γ100–200, corresponding to residues 100–235 of γ(TCT)) are located at the tip of the enzyme and not in interaction with the α3β3 hexagon (40.Hausrath A.C. Gruber G. Matthews B.W. Capaldi R.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 13697-13702Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). The ATPase activity of the α3β3γ(TCT) complex was modulated by the reduction or oxidation of the two cysteines that were introduced by the insertion of the respective part of the CF1-γ subunit. An up to 3-fold activation could be observed by the complete reduction of these cysteines (Fig. 3). As this activation ratio is in the same range as that reported for CF1 (3–7-fold) (19.Nalin C.M. McCarty R.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 7275-7280Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 20.Schwarz O. Schürmann P. Strotmann H. J. Biol. J. 1999; 341: 157-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 22.Creczynski-Pasa T.B. Graber P. FEBS Lett. 1994; 350: 195-198Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar), most likely the mechanism of thiol activation is the same in the α3β3γ(TCT) complex. Sokolovet al. (41.Sokolov M. Lu L. Tucker W. Gao F. Gegenhimer P.A. Richter M.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 13824-13829Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar) recently proposed that the conformation of the γ subunit of CF1 may be different from other F1-γ subunits. Their conclusion is based on former results of energy transfer measurements between γ subunit and the catalytic sites on β subunits (42.Moroney J.V. McCarty R.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 8951-8955Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 43.Richter M.L. Snyder B. McCarty R.E. Hammes G.G. Biochemistry. 1985; 24: 5755-5763Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar) and their investigation of the ATPase activity of a complex formed from the isolated CF1α3β3 subcomplex and recombinant γ subunit of which the C terminus was partially deleted. In their model, the tip of the C terminus of the γ subunit does not act as a spindle for rotation. However, our results indicate that a bacterial γ subunit can be transformed into a functional chloroplast-like γ subunit. Thus the essential structural features and basic functions of both types of γ subunits should be the same. This is also consistent with previous reports that upon introduction of the chloroplast γ-like regulatory stretch into the γ subunit of cyanobacterial F1 conferred thiol modulation on this enzyme (23.Werner-Grune S. Gunkel D. Schümann J. Strotmann H. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1994; 244: 144-150Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, 24.Krenn B.E. Ardewijn P. Van Walraven H.S. Werner-Grüne S. Strotmann H. Biochem. Soc. Trans. 1995; 23: 757-760Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). In this mutant both ATP hydrolysis and ATP synthesis are controlled by thiol modulation. Furthermore, ATP hydrolysis activity of a reconstituted chimeric complex containing the α and β subunits of TF1, and the γ subunit of CF1(αT3βT3γC), was regulated by thiol modulation (27.Hisabori T. Kato Y. Motohashi K. Kroth-Pancic P. Strotmann H. Amano T. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 1158-1165Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar, 28.Hisabori T. Motohashi K. Kroth P. Strotmann H. Amano T. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 15901-15905Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar) although the complex showed reduced stability. Interestingly, a higher degree of activation of the complex α3β3γ(TCT) could be achieved with a mixture of DTT and Trx-f than with DTT alone (Fig.3 B), although we could not detect a significant difference in the amount of reduced thiol groups. This is consistent with our recently proposed model that a conformational change, which affects the enzyme activity, is induced by the interaction with Trx-f(21.Stumpp M.T. Motohashi K. Hisabori T. Biochem. J. 1999; 341: 157-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). The measurement of the temperature optimum of ATPase activity shows that α3β3γ(TCT), similar to α3β3γ (β-His, γS106C), is more stable than a chimeric αT3βT3γC, which displayed the highest activity at 55–60 °C (Fig. 4, compare with Fig. 2 of Ref. 27.Hisabori T. Kato Y. Motohashi K. Kroth-Pancic P. Strotmann H. Amano T. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 1158-1165Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). This result implies that the introduction of the 148 amino acid residues from a mesophilic enzyme does not affect thermostability of the complex significantly. The most probable explanation is that the interaction between the coiled-coil structure of γ subunit and the inner surface of the cavity of α3β3 hexagon is especially important for the stability of the complex. Although the homology of this coiled-coil region of the γ subunit is relatively high (27.Hisabori T. Kato Y. Motohashi K. Kroth-Pancic P. Strotmann H. Amano T. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 1158-1165Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar), some varying amino acid residues in the coiled-coil region might be very important for the stability of the complex. Activation by DTT was not affected by the temperature, so although thiol modulation in vivo usually occurs at temperatures <30 °C in plants, it is also functional at temperatures as high as 80 °C. The ε subunit is known to be an inhibitory subunit of F1-ATPases. It has been proposed that the C-terminal helical domain of the ε subunit is mainly responsible for the inhibitory function (44.Kuki M. Noumi T. Maeda M. Amemura A. Futai M. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 17437-17442Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 45.Xiong H. Zhang D. Vik S.B. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 16423-16429Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar, 46.Kato-Yamada Y. Bald D. Koike M. Motohashi K. Hisabori T. Yoshida M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 33991-33994Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar, 47.Cruz J.A. Harfe B. Radkowski C.A. Dann M.S. McCarty R.E. Plant Physiol. (Bethesda). 1995; 109: 1379-1388Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar, 48.Hisabori T. Motohashi K. Koike M. Kroth P. Strotmann H. Amano T. Garab G. Photosynthesis: Mechanisms and Effects. 3. Kluwer Academic Publishers Group, Dordrecht, Netherlands1998: 1711-1714Google Scholar). As the ε subunit could be cross-linked to the β subunit (49.Dallmann H.G. Flynn T.G. Dunn S.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 18953-18960Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 50.Aggeler R. Haughton M.A. Capaldi R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 9185-9191Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar), the inhibition may be achieved by binding to the DELSEED region of the β subunit. We found that the ε subunit of CF1 can efficiently inhibit the ATPase activity of α3β3γ(TCT) but not that of α3β3γ (β-His, γS106C), although the α and β subunits are identical (Fig. 5). This induces the conclusion that an interaction of the ε subunit with the γ subunit may be more crucial for inhibition, possibly by providing proper binding and orientation of the ε subunit. As the sequence of the amino acid residues 92–239 of the γ subunit of α3β3γ(TCT) is different from α3β3γ (β-His, γS106C), it can be concluded that this region confers the sensitivity to inhibition by the ε subunit. Consistent with this finding, E. coliF1 residue γ106 and the region γ202–212 have previously been found to be involved in binding of the ε subunit by cross-linking and chemical labeling experiments (51.Tang C. Capaldi R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 3018-3024Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). E. coli F1-γ106 corresponds to γ(TCT)101, near the N-terminal part of the insertion from CF1, γ202–212 corresponds to γ(TCT) 234–244, located at the C terminus of the insertion (Fig. 1). Taken together, the part of the γ subunit that is of chloroplast origin in γ(TCT)appears to be crucial for binding of and inhibition by the ε subunit. As supposed from the suggested mechanism for the uni-site catalysis (29.Hiratsuka A. Uchida K. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1973; 320: 635-647Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar, 30.Grubmeyer C. Penefsky H.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 3718-3727Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), no significant differences could be detected in the rate of uni-site hydrolysis by oxidized or by reduced α3β3γ(TCT). However, we found a difference in chase acceleration of hydrolysis of TNP-ATP by the addition of excess amounts of ATP (Fig. 6). The range of the chase acceleration for the reduced α3β3γ(TCT) was comparable to that published for TF1 (35.Hisabori T. Muneyuki E. Odaka M. Yokoyama K. Mochizuki K. Yoshida M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4551-4556Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), wild type α3β3γ (32.Kato Y. Matsui T. Tanaka N. Muneyuki E. Hisabori T. Yoshida M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 24906-24912Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar), and α3β3γ (βI389C) (39.Tsunoda S.P. Muneyuki E. Amano T. Yoshida M. Noji H. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 5701-5706Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). However, significantly lower acceleration was observed for the oxidized α3β3γ(TCT), indicating an impaired interplay between the catalytic sites in the suppressed activity state caused by the formation of the disulfide bridge between Cys199 and Cys205 of the γ subunit. The regulation of the enzyme activity might be attributed to this difference observed at the chase acceleration level. The chimeric subcomplex α3β3γ(TCT) combines the property of thiol modulation, a unique feature of CF1-ATPase, with the stability and relative ease of genetic manipulation of the TF1-ATPase. It is therefore a very promising tool to investigate the structural basis and functional analyses of thiol modulation more in detail. Further experiments in this direction are under way in our laboratory. We thank E. Muneyuki, T. Suzuki, Y. Kato-Yamada, F. Motojima, T. Masaike, S. P. Tsunoda, and K. Hara for their technical assistance and helpful discussions. We particularly thank Prof. H. Strotmann (Heinrich-Heine University, Düsseldorf, Germany) and Prof. K. Kinosita (Keio University) for critically reading the manuscript.

African trypanosomes are shielded from their hosts' defenses by a coat of variant surface glycoprotein molecules, each of which is attached to the plasma membrane by a glycosylphosphatidylinositol anchor. During the later stages of glycosylphosphatidylinositol biosynthesis, myristic acid is incorporated into the anchor from the donor myristoyl-CoA by a series of unique fatty acid remodeling and exchange reactions. We have cloned and expressed a recombinant trypanosome acyl-CoA-binding protein that has a preference for binding relatively short chain acyl-CoAs and that has a high affinity for binding myristoyl-CoA (K d = 3.5 × 10−10m). This protein enhances fatty acid remodeling of glycosylphosphatidylinositol precursors in the trypanosome cell-free system. We speculate that the trypanosome acyl-CoA-binding protein plays an active role in supplying myristoyl-CoA to the fatty acid remodeling machinery in the parasite. The parasite is spread between hosts by the tsetse fly vector and, in the bloodstream, possesses a dense surface coat of 10 million copies of variant surface glycoprotein (VSG)1 (1.Cross G.A.M. Parasitol. 1975; 71: 393-417Crossref PubMed Scopus (636) Google Scholar, 2.Cross G.A.M. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1990; 6: 1-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (399) Google Scholar). The VSG coat protects the parasite from lysis by the alternative complement pathway. During an infection the parasite undergoes a process called antigenic variation whereby different VSGs are expressed on the plasma membrane (reviewed in Ref. 3.Cross G.A.M. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1990; 8: 83-110Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar). Regardless of which VSG variant is expressed on the surface, each VSG molecule is attached to the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane by a conserved glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor (4.Ferguson M.A.J. Homans S.W. Dwek R.A. Rademacher T.W. Science. 1988; 239: 753-759Crossref PubMed Scopus (553) Google Scholar). The C-terminal amino acid of the VSG protein is attached, via an ethanolamine-phosphate bridge, to a conserved moiety of Manα1–2Manα1–6Manα1–4GlcN-myo-inositol-1-HPO4-3(sn-1,2-dimyristoylglycerol) (Man3GlcN-PI). The T. brucei GPI biosynthetic pathway was elucidated using a cell-free system containing washed trypanosome membranes (5.Masterson W.J. Doering T.L. Hart G.W. Englund P.T. The pathway involves assembly of ethanolamine-P-Man3GlcN-PI (glycolipid A′) from PI followed by fatty acid remodeling whereby both fatty acids of the PI moiety are remodeled to myristate (C14:0) through the sequential deacylation and reacylation of the glycerol backbone (Fig.1). The product, a dimyristoylated GPI known as glycolipid A (8.Masterson W.J. Raper J. Doering T.L. Hart G.W. Englund P.T. Cell. 1990; 62: 73-80Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar), is linked to newly synthesized VSG in the endoplasmic reticulum by a transamidation reaction (10.Bangs J.D. Hereld D. We wished to find the trypanosome ACBP homolog and to assess the effect of including this protein in the in vitro fatty acid remodeling assays. These assays use washed membrane preparations (the so-called cell-free system) that are likely to be devoid of endogenous (soluble) ACBP.We searched GenBankTM for potential trypanosome ACBP homologs with the gene encoding human ACBP and were able to detect a trypanosome EST sequence (accession No. W40086). J. 1997; 323: 1-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (579) Google Scholar). Biochem. J. 1997; 323: 1-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (579) Google Scholar). In bovine ACBP these amino acids are Phe-5, Leu-15, Tyr-28, Lys-32, Gln-33, Gly-37, Pro-44, Lys-54, Trp-58, Gly-63, Ala-69, Tyr-73, and Leu-80. However, only six of those residues are absolutely conserved in trypanosome ACBP (Tyr-35, Gln-40, Gly-44, Pro-51, Lys-61, Ala-76) together with four conservative substitutions (Leu-6, Arg-65, Phe-80, Val-87) and three nonconservative substitutions (Thr-22, His-39, Lys-70). We considered that these differences from the other eukaryotic ACBPs studied to date might result in an altered specificity for binding acyl-CoAs. Having demonstrated that recombinant putative trypanosome ACBP was indeed a high affinity ACBP (Figs. 5 and 6), we tested the specificity of the trypanosome ACBP for acyl-CoA chain length using a competition assay (Fig. 7). These data showed that trypanosome ACBP had a distinct preference for shorter chain acyl-CoAs when compared directly to the bovine ACBP (Fig. 7).We utilized the previously resolved three-dimensional NMR structure of the complex between bovine ACBP and palmitoyl-CoA (33.Kragelund B.B. These differences may have a role in defining the chain length specificity of the two ACBPs.
